summary: China's National Development and Reform Commission has expanded its annual property survey to over 300 cities amid concerns of oversupply in smaller cities. The survey, which is usually conducted at the beginning of the year, aims to gather data on home and land sales and prices to inform government policies. The move comes as home prices and sales have weakened this year, with developers cutting prices and the government seeking advice from developers on property policies. The survey's expansion aims to provide a better understanding of local market conditions.

site_title: AirAsia India gets its first A320
summary: AirAsia India, the Indian unit of budget carrier AirAsia, received its first Airbus 320 at Chennai, bringing the airline closer to launching domestic operations. The carrier's CEO, Mittu Chandilya, stated that the delivery marks a step towards creating a benchmark in low-cost air travel in India. Despite initial resistance from existing Indian airlines, the director general of civil aviation has cleared the way for AirAsia India to operate, citing the need for new entrants to provide affordable services.

site_title: Trust in govts has fallen in many countries: Tharman
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam stated that trust in governments has fallen globally, with 17 of 27 countries under study having trust below 50% this year, according to the Edelman Barometer of Trust. Despite this, Singapore remains among the 10 countries with a majority trusting the government. Tharman emphasized the need for the government to improve public services, innovate, and communicate effectively to meet rising expectations, particularly from the younger generation, and engage Singaporeans in governance processes.

site_title: 2014 to be strong year for IPOs: EY
summary: This year is shaping up to be a strong year for initial public offerings (IPOs) with 239 deals closed in Q1, raising a record-breaking US$44.3 billion. The first quarter broke the record for the best-performing first quarter for the global IPO market since 2011, with 47% higher deal numbers and 82% more capital raised compared to the same period last year. Asia-Pacific was the most active region, with 110 IPOs raising US$18.1 billion, driven by the reopening of mainland China's stock exchanges and a pipeline of around 700 companies ready to go public.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Global Premium Hotels' offer price for shares remains unchanged at 33 cents apiece, with no extension of the offer period beyond April 24. DBS Bank announced on behalf of chairman Koh Wee Meng, who has acquired a 62.4% stake in the company. Meanwhile, GSH Corporation acquired a 77.5% stake in Sutera Harbour Resort Group in Malaysia for RM700 million. Hyflux International signed a joint venture agreement with Tolaram Corporation to develop membrane-based water treatment plants in Nigeria.

site_title: No joke, the comedians are coming!
summary: The Magners Singapore International Comedy Festival will take place from April 23 to 26, featuring 38 well-known comedians from around the world. The festival, organized by Magic Rock, will allow attendees to hop between 10 bars in Boat Quay to watch their preferred comedians. The event aims to boost the Singapore comedy scene, which has gained popularity, with some local comedians participating as hosts, learning from international comedians and gaining exposure. The festival is expected to be a success, with ticket sales already showing promise, and organizers plan to double the festival's size next year.

site_title: Important for S'pore to build up nuclear safety expertise: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said the country does not plan to establish a research institute dedicated to nuclear energy, but it's essential to build up nuclear safety expertise through other means. Lee stated that Singapore's vast safety distances and scale requirements make it unlikely to generate nuclear power domestically. However, Singapore has a vested interest in understanding nuclear power to address neighboring countries' growing energy needs and diversify away from oil. The country is building up its expertise gradually through universities and research institutes to advise the government on nuclear safety and options.

site_title: KSH-Lian Beng unit in Cambodia property deal
summary: IMPERIAL South East Asia Investment (ISEA) is forming a joint venture to acquire a US$64 million land in Cambodia, with plans to redevelop the existing hotel. ISEA, 34.7% owned by KSH Holdings and 32.65% owned by Lian Beng Group, will fund its 49% stake with a US$31.4 million bond issue. The joint venture, New Global Imperial Investment, will be incorporated with a registered capital of US$5,000, and will be owned 49% by ISEA and 51% by Lok Oknha Sear Rithy. Redevelopment plans are at a preliminary stage.

site_title: EPC projects in UK, Qatar challenging: Keppel CEO
summary: Keppel Corporation's new CEO, Loh Chin Hua, stated that the company is working under challenging conditions to deliver EPC projects with minimal losses. The CEO attributed cost overruns in Qatar and the UK to projects taking longer than expected to complete. Keppel's infrastructure division reported significant losses, including $111 million in Q4 2013, due to challenges in EPC contracts. Loh emphasized the importance of sticking to core competencies and re-evaluating value chains to add value consistently.

site_title: Air China shares dip on 32% profit drop
summary: Air China shares dropped 2.51% in Hong Kong after reporting a 32% decline in net profit to 3.32 billion yuan (S$677 million) in 2013, due to a weak cargo market and global economic struggles. Revenue decreased 2.2% to 97.63 billion yuan. The airline attributed the decline to intensified competition and a sluggish cargo market, with revenue from mainland China operations falling 3.31% to 64.39 billion yuan. Looking ahead, Air China expects the aviation industry to face challenges such as rising operating costs and competition.

site_title: SGX fixing revamped website after complaints
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has revamped its company announcements webpage, which has caused frustration among users due to user-unfriendly features. The issues included difficulties in searching for announcements by real estate investment trusts (Reits) and business trusts, and problems with the layout and readability of the page. After fixing the issues, users can now search more easily for Reits and the page will be made more readable. The fixes were implemented after complaints from users and analysts, and SGX has promised to continue improving the page through future phases.

site_title: Cutting utilities costs and carbon emissions
summary: Singapore is addressing high utilities costs for the refining and petrochemical industry, with the government developing a "heat integration" plan to share excess heat and steam among plants on Jurong Island. The Economic Development Board aims to stabilize power prices by facilitating alternative energy options, such as biomass and energy-from-waste generation, and diversifying gas supplies through liquefied natural gas imports. In-house co-generation plants, like ExxonMobil's, reduce costs and greenhouse gas emissions, but smaller industry players may struggle to invest in such facilities.

site_title: NY offices deck up to lure creative clients
summary: A New York City office building is transforming its space to appeal to creative companies, following the city's growing dependence on the creative sectors. The 285 Madison Ave building offers a "lifestyle" experience, including a communal roof deck, fitness center, and bike storage room. This effort is part of a larger shift in the city's commercial market, with Midtown South emerging as a hub for startups and blue-chip tenants. Rents in the area are expected to increase, with a 15-30% premium over the market, as tenants prioritize amenities and work-life balance.

site_title: Facebook pays US$2b for virtual reality headgear firm
summary: Facebook has acquired Oculus, a virtual reality headgear firm, for $2 billion. The acquisition is part of Facebook's plan to build the "next major computing platform" and make its offerings more immersive. Oculus, launched in 2012, is considered a leader in immersive virtual reality technology and has garnered over 75,000 pre-orders for its $350 headset. Facebook plans to make Oculus technology available for communications, education, and entertainment, and will maintain its headquarters in California. The deal marks a significant move by Facebook to expand its presence in the tech industry.

site_title: PM Lee: Singapore keen on new air transport deal with EU
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressed the country's eagerness for a new air transport deal with the European Union, aiming to increase flights and opportunities for business and tourism. The proposed deal, if successful, would pave the way for a wider open-skies agreement between the EU and the Association of South-east Asian Nations. Luxembourg Prime Minister Xavier Bettel backed the deal, stating it would take time before negotiations can begin.

site_title: Mandarin Oriental to expand Munich hotel
summary: Mandarin Oriental International is expanding its hotel in Munich with a 124 million euro (S$217 million) refurbishment and construction of a mixed-use complex on an adjacent site. The existing hotel will be enhanced with 73 refurbished rooms, while the new complex, opening in 2021, will feature 19 luxury residences, retail units, commercial offices, and underground car parking. The project is expected to generate US$17 million in incremental EBITDA in 2023.

site_title: SIA's $500m bond issue snapped up
summary: Singapore Airlines successfully tapped the debt market with a $500 million bond issue, the largest non-financial corporate deal this year. The bonds, sold in two tranches, were priced at 3.145% and 3.75% respectively, and were mainly allocated to institutional investors. The deal, led by DBS Bank, was confident in pricing without a range, and the bonds are already trading higher, with yields at 3.113% and 3.725% for the seven-year and 10-year tranches, respectively.

site_title: Law firm to file suit against Boeing, MAS in US
summary: A US-based law firm, Ribbeck Law, plans to represent families of over half of MH370 passengers in a lawsuit against Boeing and Malaysian Airlines, alleging mechanical failure caused the plane to crash into the Indian Ocean, killing all 239 on board. The lawsuit seeks millions of dollars in compensation and demands Boeing repair its 777 fleet. The law firm believes mechanical failure, rather than hijacking or pilot suicide, was the cause of the disaster, citing experience from previous incidents.

site_title: Kampong Glam shophouse block up for sale
summary: A detached shophouse block at Kampong Glam and three adjoining plots of GCB land are up for sale, with an indicative price of $28 million for the shophouse and $1,500 psf for the GCB plots. The shophouse, leased to a food and beverage tenant until 2015, is zoned for commercial use and sits on a 7,401 sq ft land area. The GCB plots, vacant and accessible via two cul-de-sacs, offer a rare opportunity to acquire large-sized land. Despite market slowdown, conservation shophouses remain an attractive investment option.

site_title: SGX site is now counter-intuitive
summary: The Singapore Exchange's (SGX) revamped "company announcements" section has become counter-intuitive, making it harder for retail investors to access and understand corporate news and updates. The change affects real estate investment trusts (Reits) and business trusts, requiring users to search for the company name managing the trust, rather than the trust itself. This change has been met with criticism, as it complicates the process of accessing important information.

site_title: Singapore factory output up 12.8% in Feb
summary: Singapore's factory output surged 12.8% in February, driven by strong growth in biomedical, electronics, and transport engineering sectors. However, economists expect a sequential pullback in Q1 GDP of around 0.5%, citing base and seasonal effects. Despite the strong manufacturing output, economists caution that the data may be flattered by volatile components, making it hard to draw strong conclusions. Excluding the biomedical cluster, output would still have risen 11.2% year-on-year. Economists expect a normalisation of industrial production to the mid-single-digit range from March onwards.

site_title: US black box detector arrives in Australia
summary: A US black box detector designed to locate the wreckage of Malaysian Airlines Flight MH370 has arrived in Australia, where a dozen aircraft are searching the southern Indian Ocean for debris. The detector, along with an undersea Navy drone, will aid in the recovery of the cockpit voice recorder and flight data recorder, which could unlock clues about the plane's diversion off course. The search zone, 2,500km south-west of Perth, has seen bad weather and inaccessibility hinder recovery efforts, but Australian authorities remain confident that wreckage will be found.

site_title: Prudential Singapore seeing more interest in bancassurance
summary: Prudential Singapore is seeing increased interest from banks in offering bancassurance, with its new business sales reaching $706 million, a 18% increase from the previous year. The company will extend its 15-year bancassurance partnership with Standard Chartered for another 15 years, covering Asian markets. Prudential's bancassurance channels, which include partnerships with banks, UOB, Maybank, and SingPost, contributed to the growth, with a focus on high net worth individuals and those over 40 years old.

site_title: Singapore Maritime Week the biggest yet
summary: The Singapore Maritime Week (SMW) is set to take place from April 6 to 11, featuring a record 29 events and aiming to engage a wider audience, including the public and young people. The event, driven by the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore, will focus on the theme of "People, Ideas and Opportunities" and will include thought leadership events, conferences, and exhibitions. The week-long event is expected to attract a large number of participants, with the goal of promoting Singapore as a thought leadership hub in the maritime industry and fostering business relationships.

site_title: Addvalue deal: do the values add up?
summary: Addvalue Technologies plans to sell its subsidiary, Addvalue Communications, to a Chinese buyer for $330 million in cash, resulting in a 149% surge in the company's share price. However, the buyer's identity and the valuation of the subsidiary are unclear, with some questioning the premium paid and whether the deal warrants a "Trade With Caution" notice from the Singapore Exchange. The buyer's name is listed as Tiancheng Hengsheng (Beijing) Technology Limited, but other companies share the same Chinese characters, raising suspicions. The deal's terms, including a non-refundable $33 million deposit and a $15 million commission, have also raised questions.

site_title: Fresh sightings of 122 objects
summary: Malaysia's search for the missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 has yielded new leads, with 122 objects spotted in the southern Indian Ocean, 2,557km from Perth. The objects, ranging from 1m to 23m in length, were identified by satellite images and may be debris from the ill-fated Boeing 777. The search operation has narrowed the zone to the southern tip of the southern Indian Ocean and is being led by Australia, with six planes and two ships deployed to the area.

site_title: Inspections of cruise ships reveal leaky lifeboats, faulty doors
summary: US maritime inspectors found 140 cruise ships, mostly flagged in other countries, with leaky lifeboats or faulty fire doors during 2013 inspections in US ports. The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) forum in Washington highlighted the issues, following several high-profile scandals in the cruise industry. The inspections revealed problems with lifeboats, fire doors, and other safety equipment, sparking concerns about the safety of passengers and crew.

site_title: Banks eyeing Alibaba IPO skip some US$100m of business
summary: Banks participating in Alibaba's initial public offering (IPO) are avoiding work for its rivals and acquisition targets, potentially missing out on an estimated $100 million in combined fees. The banks, including Citigroup, Credit Suisse, and Goldman Sachs, are concerned about potential conflicts and leaks of confidential information. The competition for the IPO is fierce, with estimated fees totaling $300 million, making it the biggest Chinese fee payer to global investment banks in a decade.

site_title: HK banks' US$430b exposure to China sparks concern
summary: Hong Kong banks have significantly increased their exposure to China, with US$430 billion in loans, representing 40% of their total loan book and 165% of Hong Kong's GDP. This surge in lending has raised concerns about the credit exposure to China, particularly amid sliding economic growth and loan defaults. The high exposure to China's property and financial sectors, as well as industries with surplus output capacity, has regulators' attention.

site_title: Houston channel remains shut
summary: The Houston Ship Channel remains closed, threatening to extend its shutdown to a fourth day. The Coast Guard is working to clean up an oil barge spill, but progress has been slow. Ship operators were initially told to expect a partial reopening, but officials now estimate it may take longer. The closure has forced Exxon Mobil Corp to cut production at its Baytown, Texas refinery, with further cuts expected if the channel remains shut. A queue of over 90 vessels is waiting to enter or exit the Gulf of Mexico.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Malaysia's search for the missing MH370 jet has narrowed to the southern Indian Ocean. Hong Kong banks have a significant exposure to China, sparking concerns about their credit exposure. The Nuclear Security Summit aims to set a new direction for tackling nuclear terrorism. Market volatility boosts the oil market, while Singapore companies remain bullish on Asia's growth. Retail rents stagnate in Q1, and Malaysia's Kian Joo accepts a bid of RM1.47 billion. Beijing may intervene to support its economy, and Cisco invests $1 billion in cloud computing.

site_title: Time to start shifting assets to emerging markets: SocGen
summary: French bank Societe Generale recommends shifting assets to emerging markets, particularly Asian stocks, due to undervaluation and limited risk of further slippage. Emerging markets have been hit hard by outflows and currency devaluations, but SocGen sees potential for recovery, favoring Asian equities due to correlation with US manufacturing. The bank also expects Chinese equities to benefit from government stimulus, despite an economic slowdown.

site_title: EFG Bank sees larger AUM contribution from Asia
summary: EFG Bank expects its Asian operations to contribute 40% to assets under management (AUM) by "not-too-distant future", translating to around US$18 billion. The bank has been awarded a wholesale banking licence in Singapore, allowing it to accept Singapore-dollar deposits and offer Singapore dollar-denominated products. EFG's strategy in Asia focuses on engaging senior bankers to bring in clients, with a goal of making Asia the bank's largest contributing region in AUM terms.

site_title: San Miguel to present plan for US$10b airport to govt
summary: San Miguel Corp plans to present a US$10 billion proposal to the Philippine government for a new international airport in Manila, to complement the ageing Ninoy Aquino International Airport. The project, which would be built under a build-operate-transfer scheme, would include four runways on an 800-hectare property. The airport's ownership would be turned over to the government after 25 years. The proposal comes as the government is also studying the possibility of converting a former US navy base into an alternative international airport, with a similar capacity.

site_title: Search efforts narrow for MH370
summary: Malaysia has narrowed its search for the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 to the southern Indian Ocean, where it is believed to have ended. Australia will lead the search efforts, spanning 470,000 square nautical miles near the south-west coast of Australia. The decision comes after data analysis by British satellite company Inmarsat and UK Air Accidents Investigation Branch (AAIB) indicated the plane's possible final position. Malaysia Airlines and its chief, Ahmad Jauhari Yahya, face criticism and anger from relatives of Chinese passengers, with some calling for his resignation.

images.alt_text: After scouring more than two million square nautical miles for MH370 since it disappeared 18 days ago, the search operations for the missing aircraft with 239 passengers and crew has now been narrowed to the southern tip of the freezing southern Indian Ocean - PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Singapore Airlines raised $500 million in a bond issue, snapping up the debt market. This year is expected to be strong for IPOs, with 239 deals raising $44.3 billion in the first quarter. Singapore's industrial output surged 12.8% in February, but GDP growth is still expected to slow in Q1. The country is seeking a new air transport deal with the EU, while a China buyer is set to acquire Addvalue Technologies' subsidiary for $330 million. Meanwhile, China's struggling firms are receiving smaller, costlier loans, and Singapore's Maritime Week is expected to be the biggest yet.

site_title: Carriers should right-size fleets: jet manufacturers
summary: Asian carriers should right-size their fleets to address infrastructure constraints, enabling faster turn-around times and greater frequencies on regional routes. Smaller jets allow for quicker turnaround times, maximizing airport infrastructure and improving passenger choice. Industry experts, including Embraer's Mark Dunnachie, emphasize the need for carriers to use the right tools for the job, rather than over-ordering planes based on growing demand expectations.

site_title: Boustead unit wins water treatment deal
summary: Boustead Salcon Water Solutions Pte Ltd, a subsidiary of Boustead Singapore Ltd, has secured a major multi-million dollar contract to design and supply water and wastewater treatment facilities in Indonesia. The contract, valued at $35 million, is part of a 2,000 MW coal-fired thermal power plant project. This deal increases Boustead's order book backlog to $400 million and solidifies its position as a preferred complete technology provider for water and wastewater BOP in the energy sector.

site_title: TPV to acquire Philips stake in TP Vision
summary: TPV Technology Limited has agreed to acquire Philips' 30% stake in TP Vision for a deferred purchase price of four times the average proportional earnings before interest and tax (EBIT). The new price cap for 100% of TP Vision's shares is US$350 million. Philips will cease to hold any shares in TP Vision, and the company will become an indirect wholly owned subsidiary of TPV. A supplemental trademark licence agreement also reduces Philips' guaranteed minimum annual royalty to 40 million euros (S$70 million).

site_title: Genting HK gets SGX nod for secondary listing
summary: Genting Hong Kong has received in-principle approval from Singapore Exchange (SGX) for a secondary listing by way of introduction on the main board, allowing its shares to be traded in Hong Kong dollars and US dollars. The introduction is subject to certain conditions and does not involve the offering of new shares. Analysts expect trading liquidity to remain unchanged, with some viewing the move as a formalization process. The secondary listing may attract more institutional investors, particularly if it is included in a benchmark index.

site_title: Japan looks compelling again for private equity
summary: Japan is becoming more attractive to private equity investors due to the government's economic policy shift, "Abenomics," and reforms by large Japanese corporates. This has led to a surge in deals, with private equity funds focusing on small- and medium-sized enterprises, which represent 99% of all Japanese companies. The market has significant room to grow, but investors need to carefully select private equity fund managers with local and seasoned investment teams to execute deals effectively.

site_title: Addvalue to sell subsidiary for $330m
summary: Addvalue Technologies is selling its subsidiary, Addvalue Communications Pte Ltd, for $330 million in cash. The sale, conditional on shareholder and regulatory approvals, aims to "unlock the value of the group," particularly its China business. The deal represents a 1,883% premium to the net asset value of AVC. Addvalue will consider using the sale proceeds for a special dividend or other options. The sale does not impact the company's other subsidiaries, and business will continue as usual.

site_title: Feb inflation sinks to 4-year low, but expected to rise again
summary: Singapore's inflation rate fell to a four-year low of 0.4% in February, beating economists' expectations of 0.9%. However, experts warn that the rate is likely to rise again due to pent-up wage pressures, rising food prices, and a weakening Singapore dollar. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is unlikely to ease monetary policy at its upcoming April meeting, citing expected inflation to rise above 2% in the next few months.

site_title: Riding on crest of megatrends
summary: Pictet Asset Management has seen significant success with its thematic investment approach, with investors committing US$20 billion to its funds. The firm identifies megatrends, such as globalisation, polarisation, and economic growth, which are long-lasting and attractive for investment. Nine thematic funds, including the Pictet Water fund, have outperformed the MSCI World index since their inception. Pictet takes a systematic approach to thematic investing, focusing on valuation and long-term growth potential, and is able to adapt to changes in trends, repositioning funds as needed.

site_title: S'pore yards can compete and win on quality
summary: Singapore shipyards can compete and win by focusing on high-quality, specialized vessels, according to George Horsington, president of business development at Jaya Holdings. The influx of "cheap builds" from China, particularly in the smaller offshore vessel market, poses a threat to Singapore yards. However, Horsington believes that by emphasizing quality and specialized designs, Singapore yards can maintain their competitive edge and survive. This shift in focus is crucial for yards to remain competitive in the market.

site_title: SingHealth's Cycle of Life in BT Charity Challenge
summary: Eight SingHealth representatives will participate in the OCBC Cycle Singapore, a 39km cycling event, on Sunday to raise awareness for organ and tissue donation. The event is part of the Business Times Charity Challenge, which benefits SingHealth Transplant TRUEfund and Dover Park Hospice. The cyclists will wear specially designed jerseys with the theme "The Cycle of Life" to highlight the importance of transplantation. The funds raised will support needy transplant recipients, transplant education, and research.

site_title: KrisEnergy secures US$100m revolving credit facility
summary: KrisEnergy secures a $100 million revolving credit facility to be used for acquiring hydrocarbon assets, working capital, and general corporate purposes. The facility, set to mature in March 2016, is secured by the company's existing assets in the Gulf of Thailand and Bangladesh. The company plans to optimize its balance sheet to achieve its development projects and organic growth goals. This is KrisEnergy's sixth capital markets transaction in its five-year history.

site_title: Alliance of top 3 shipping lines may start in mid-2014
summary: A proposed alliance between Maersk Line, MSC Mediterranean Shipping Company, and CMA CGM is set to start operating in mid-2014, pooling 250 ships on three trade routes. The alliance, known as P3, aims to cut costs by running larger, more fuel-efficient vessels. However, critics fear it could dominate the market, pushing out smaller carriers and driving up prices. The US Federal Maritime Commission has approved the alliance for routes to and from US ports, with European and Chinese regulators still to give the green light.

site_title: Flash China PMI shows factory output weakened again in March
summary: China's manufacturing industry weakened for a fifth straight month, according to the preliminary Purchasing Managers' Index, which dropped to 48.1, below the 48.7 median estimate. This deepens concerns the nation will miss its 7.5% growth target this year. Chinese stocks rebounded on speculation of policy makers reconsidering broad stimulus measures, while leaders face a balancing act between reining in credit expansion and averting an economic slump.

site_title: S'pore firms bullish about growth in Asia: poll
summary: A survey by Telstra Global found that 60% of Singapore companies exceeded financial and strategic objectives in the past three years, with 43% expecting to continue doing so in the next three years. The survey also found that Western companies are performing better in Asia, with 66% meeting their objectives and 27% exceeding them. The survey identified "Asia Business Champions" as companies that have struck a balance between expansion and consolidation, with 45% rating expansion as "very important" and 56% rating consolidation as "highly important".

site_title: American to revive an era of glamour
summary: American Airlines is reviving its glamorous past with a new advertising campaign highlighting its decades of service on US transcontinental routes. The campaign features actors such as Grace Kelly, Gregory Peck, and Julianna Margulies, and emphasizes the airline's legacy as the first to offer non-stop transcontinental flights in 1953. American has introduced new flights on Airbus A321 aircraft, offering three classes of service and in-flight Wi-Fi and entertainment. The airline is battling with Delta and United for corporate travelers, and JetBlue will introduce new "Mint" service in June.

site_title: Finding MH370's black boxes a huge challenge
summary: Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, a Boeing 777 with 239 people on board, crashed into the southern Indian Ocean on March 8, 2014. The search for its black boxes, which contain flight data and cockpit voice recordings, is expected to be long and difficult due to the remote location and vast search zone. The black boxes are believed to emit tracking signals for about two weeks, but no confirmed debris has been found. Specialists recommend cataloguing every piece of debris discovered, deploying data buoys, and using remote-operated vehicles to search the area, which could take months or more.

site_title: Indonesia eyes growth in offshore sector
summary: Indonesia aims to reverse its position as a net energy importer by increasing oil and gas exploration & production spending. The country is poised to become a growth area for the offshore industry, with opportunities for companies to rejuvenate older tonnage, prepare port infrastructure, and develop the Eastern Indonesian ports. The Indonesian National Shipowners' Association sees the offshore support vessel market as a key area for growth, with the government planning to develop it next year. However, challenges include attracting private companies and securing substantial investment and knowledge transfer.

site_title: When the consumer of shipping services doesn't pay enough
summary: The liner shipping industry is struggling due to intense competition and unprofitable freight rates, with many carriers expected to report losses this year. The introduction of mega container ships has increased capital costs, while environmental regulations are expected to further spike operating costs. The industry is turning to consolidation, with proposed alliances and mergers aimed at reducing overtonnage and increasing efficiency. However, this consolidation is likely to lead to higher prices for shipping services, as the industry seeks to stem losses and make the current position unsustainable in the long term.

site_title: MH370 crashed into Indian Ocean: Najib
summary: Malaysia Airlines flight MH370, carrying 239 people, crashed into the southern Indian Ocean, according to new analysis of satellite data by Inmarsat and the UK air accidents unit. The jet flew along the southern corridor and its last position was west of Perth, a remote location far from possible landing sites. Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak confirmed the fate of the plane, saying it ended in the Indian Ocean, with no survivors. The cause of the diversion remains unclear, and search efforts continue.

site_title: UIC's SingLand offer 'fair and reasonable'
summary: UIC's takeover offer for Singapore Land (SingLand) has been deemed "fair and reasonable" by independent directors and financial adviser ANZ. The offer price of $9.40 per share is a 11.24% premium to the last traded price and a 13.87% premium to the volume-weighted average price for the past three months. ANZ noted that the offer provides an opportunity for shareholders to cash out at a premium to market prices without incurring trading commission and other costs.

site_title: Expansion only if Heathrow gets 3rd runway: Branson
summary: Virgin Atlantic founder Richard Branson warned that Britain is at risk of "slipping into the dark ages" without a third runway at London's Heathrow airport. He stated that Virgin will only expand its domestic carrier Little Red into Europe after a third runway is built, citing difficulties in getting slots at Heathrow. Branson's comments come after Little Red launched routes from Heathrow to Manchester and Scottish cities last year, with some analysts initially expecting expansion to attract transatlantic feeder traffic.

site_title: Game of couch potatoes: HBO is coming
summary: HBO is expanding its international presence, having recently acquired majority ownership of its international joint ventures and buying out partners in regions such as Asia and South Asia. The company's CEO, Richard Plepler, expects a double-digit compounded annual growth rate in international revenue as the market continues to grow. HBO is launching its streaming service, HBO Go, in select countries, including Hong Kong and the Philippines, but faces challenges related to content regulation and piracy. Despite competition from Netflix, Plepler remains confident in HBO's ability to produce high-quality content and attract a global audience.

site_title: World leaders eye new direction in tackling nuclear terror
summary: World leaders at the Nuclear Security Summit (NSS) in The Hague have agreed to turn international guidelines on nuclear security into national laws, with 35 of the 53 countries involved pledging to "realise or exceed" the standards set by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA). The US will host the next NSS in 2016, and the summit's leaders have discussed a new direction for tackling nuclear terrorism, with the IAEA seen as a suitable institution to take charge.

site_title: Not possible to do away with nuclear energy entirely: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for a robust international framework to manage nuclear safety and security at the Nuclear Security Summit in The Hague. Despite the Fukushima disaster, it's not possible to eliminate nuclear energy entirely, and Singapore will accede to the Convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Material. Lee stressed the importance of securing both civilian and non-civilian nuclear materials and facilities, and international cooperation is crucial in preventing nuclear proliferation.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: OXLEY Holdings invested 90 million yuan (S$18.54 million) in a Chinese joint venture, with a 50:50 partnership in property development. Aberdeen International Fund Managers disposed of 585,000 EYS shares, reducing its stake to 4.946%. UE E&C's controlling shareholder is in talks to sell its stake in the company. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Singapore stocks rose for a fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: K-Green Trust seeks wider investment mandate
summary: K-Green Trust, a Singapore-based infrastructure investment trust, is seeking to expand its investment mandate to cover a wider range of infrastructure assets. The trust currently owns three waste-to-energy plants and plans to focus on acquisitions in gas, waste, and alternative energy sectors. The proposed changes include a shift in sponsor to Keppel Infrastructure and a revised Rights of First Refusal Deed. The trust's name is also set to change to Keppel Infrastructure Trust. Unitholders will vote on the necessary modifications at an extraordinary general meeting on April 15, 2014.

site_title: MinLaw seeks public feedback on proposed changes to legal framework
summary: The Ministry of Law (MinLaw) in Singapore is seeking public feedback on proposed changes to the legal framework, including a single regulatory framework for foreign-qualified and Singapore-qualified lawyers. The changes also include the establishment of a dedicated regulator to oversee the industry and the introduction of mandatory pro-bono reporting for lawyers. The public has until April 11 to submit its views on the proposed amendments, contained in the Legal Profession (Amendment) Bill 2014.

site_title: Sub-800 sq ft units' share of new sales hits record
summary: In Singapore, small units of up to 800 square feet made up a record 47.6% of non-landed private homes sold by developers last year, up from 43.4% in 2013. This trend is attributed to developers reducing unit sizes to keep prices affordable for buyers, particularly investors, who face tighter loan limits. The share of 500-800 sq ft units increased to 34.4% last year, while shoebox units (below 500 sq ft) dropped to 13.2%.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak announced that Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 crashed into the southern Indian Ocean 17 days ago, killing all 239 people on board. Meanwhile, a record proportion of non-landed private homes sold by developers in Singapore last year were units under 800 square feet, making up 47.6% of sales. In other news, a 600-tonne silver vault was opened in Singapore, and Singapore's inflation rate eased to a four-year low of 0.4% in February.

site_title: Banks not playing to their edge: report
summary: A recent report by Oliver Wyman and Morgan Stanley suggests that mid-sized banks, including those in Singapore, are struggling to build effective strategies to utilize their capital due to tougher regulations. The report notes that most banks lack urgency in building thoughtful strategies, and that corporate banking revenue is expected to decline due to over-competition and low client payback. To adapt, mid-sized banks may need to evolve into broad service providers, product specialists, and focus on areas such as trade financing and long-term financing for infrastructure projects.

site_title: Tiger orders 37 Airbus planes worth US$3.8b
summary: Tiger Airways has ordered 37 Airbus A320neo aircraft worth $3.8 billion, with deliveries starting in 2018. The airline cancelled nine A320 aircraft scheduled for delivery this year and next, and also has options for 13 additional aircraft to be converted to A321neo models, expected to save $40 million annually in fuel costs.

site_title: Albedo's RTO deal hanging on tenterhooks
summary: Albedo's reverse takeover (RTO) deal with Malaysian tycoon Danny Tan has hit a roadblock, with shares recovering slightly after a 40% plunge last week. The deal, worth $1.86 billion, was reported to be on the verge of collapse after Tan's representatives requested a mutually terminated deal. Albedo has denied any agreement to scrap the deal, but investors remain cautious amid concerns over the Sultan of Johor's involvement and potential conflict of interest with Tropicana Corp. The deal's fate remains uncertain, leaving investors and stakeholders waiting for further updates.

site_title: 38 units at The Draycott up for sale
summary: The investment holding company Tan Chwee Boon Pte Ltd has put up 38 units for sale at The Draycott, valued at $1,900 per square foot, totaling $198 million. The units, representing 31% of the development, include 30 tower block units facing Goodwood Hill.

site_title: Malaysia faces longer-term challenges too
summary: Malaysia faces significant long-term challenges, including a declining GDP growth rate, stagnant corruption perception, and a struggling education system. The country's 2020 "Wawasan 2020" vision of becoming a fully developed nation is at risk due to its 4.7% GDP growth in 2013, below its average annual growth of 4.9% from 2000-2012. The World Bank forecasts 4.8% growth in 2014 and 2015, falling short of the 6% needed to achieve the 2020 objective. Corruption and brain drain issues also pose concerns for Malaysia's future growth.

site_title: Good corporate citizenship
summary: Business leaders from Singapore's top companies, including SAP, Courts Asia, DBS, Clifford Chance, UPS, IBM, Credit Suisse, and StarHub, emphasize the importance of corporate social responsibility (CSR) in driving business success. They highlight the need for enterprises to align their CSR efforts with social causes that generate value for both the business and community. The leaders stress that CSR should be a key pillar of an organization's business model and operations, leveraging core competencies to support causes they are passionate about. They also emphasize the importance of sustainability, collaboration with NGOs, and engaging employees, customers, and business partners to share in CSR initiatives.

site_title: 600-tonne vault for silver opens amid robust demand
summary: Silver Bullion, a Singapore-based bullion retailer, has opened a 600-tonne silver vault, known as The Safe House, amid strong demand for physical bullion. The vault, which also stores 30 tonnes of gold, is the first of its kind for a bullion retailer in Singapore. Customers will be the legal title owners of precious metals stored there, and are covered by insurance for up to US$100 million. The move comes as demand for silver and other precious metals in Singapore continues to grow, driven by concerns over the US dollar and growing government debt.

site_title: Q1 investment sales of property remain sluggish
summary: Singapore's Q1 investment sales in property remain sluggish, with total sales volume at $3.8 billion, the lowest since 2009. Deals from the public sector, primarily state land sales, account for 61.3% of transactions, while the residential sector makes up 58.6% of total sales value. Savills predicts the final figure will be slightly higher than Q4's $3.9 billion. The slowdown is attributed to a slowdown in transactions during Chinese New Year festivities and high asking prices resulting in a price gap between buyers and sellers.

site_title: China Fishery secures US$650m credit facility
summary: China Fishery Group Limited has secured a US$650 million credit facility to refinance debt and fund its expanded operations following the acquisition of Copeinca ASA. The new facility will help reduce average interest expenses and extend debt maturity, with a four-year term. The company has also decided not to renew a Long-Term Supply Agreement, aiming to redeploy capital and improve its capital structure. However, Fitch Ratings has downgraded China Fishery's credit profile due to increased debt and a weakened net leverage ratio of 4.9 times by the end of 2013.

site_title: French satellite images too point to debris
summary: Malaysia says new French satellite images show possible debris from missing Malaysian Airlines Flight MH370 deep in the southern Indian Ocean. The images, combined with Chinese and Australian satellite images, suggest the plane may have crashed in remote seas off Australia. The search effort entered its third week with no confirmed trace of the Boeing 777. Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott expressed "increasing hope" of a breakthrough in the hunt for the plane, which vanished on March 8 with 239 people on board.

site_title: A stroll through the shopping mall sector
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The profitability of Singapore's shopping malls depends on their tenant mix, space use, and population growth. Reit (Real Estate Investment Trust) investors look for stability and income, favoring suburban malls with grocery chains and movie theaters. Renovations (AEI) and strategic tenant mixes are key to boosting profits. Location and size also play a crucial role, with malls near MRT stations and larger ones having more flexibility. Despite online shopping's rise, brick-and-mortar malls are expected to remain profitable, with certain items like clothing and shoes still benefiting from in-store experiences.

site_title: Changi passenger traffic in Feb dips marginally
summary: Changi Airport saw a 0.2% year-on-year decline in passenger traffic to 4.1 million in February, while freight traffic dropped 2.6% to 127,681 tonnes. Aircraft landings and take-offs increased 3.2%. The decline may be attributed to protests in Bangkok and the cessation of non-stop flights to the Americas. However, traffic to North-east Asia, South-east Asia, and South Asia grew, with destinations like Bali and Kuala Lumpur experiencing double-digit growth. This marks a 3.1% increase in passenger throughput for the first two months of the year.

site_title: Singapore developers with China exposure on firm footing
summary: Singapore property developers with significant China exposure, such as Yanlord Land Group and Ying Li International, are not expected to be affected by the rising financing costs in China due to their diversified financing sources and strong credit-worthiness. Despite concerns over potential defaults by debt-laden local players, larger Singapore developers can still raise financing across the dollar and offshore CNH market, and some analysts see opportunities for them to acquire distressed targets.

site_title: Unionmet sheds light on rights puzzle
summary: Unionmet, an Indium manufacturer, clarified that substantial shareholder Precious Stream Holdings (PSH) had its rights entitlement scaled down to 23.9 million shares from 87.9 million to avoid triggering a mandatory takeover. The move kept PSH's shareholding below 30% after the company issued 56.6 million new shares, down from the original 306.8 million. The scaling back prevented PSH from exceeding the 30% threshold, which would have triggered a mandatory takeover offer.

site_title: Shadow of Russia hangs over Nuclear Security Summit
summary: More than 50 world leaders gathered in the Netherlands for a two-day Nuclear Security Summit, overshadowed by the escalating crisis in Ukraine. The US and its G-7 allies discussed Russia's annexation of Crimea, while Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov met with US Secretary of State John Kerry. The summit also featured a key trilateral meeting between US President Barack Obama, South Korean President Park Geun Hye, and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, focusing on ties between Seoul and Tokyo. The event aims to prevent nuclear materials from falling into terrorist hands.

site_title: SingTel offers new cloud communications service
summary: SingTel has launched a Unified Communications-as-a-Service (UCaaS) offering, providing enterprises in the Asia-Pacific region with a cloud-based communications solution. The service includes voice, video, messaging, and presence, and can be deployed quickly without long provisioning lead times. UCaaS is hosted in SingTel's data centers and offers a scalable and flexible solution for businesses. The service is available on a per-employee monthly subscription scheme, catering to desk-bound and mobile users, and is designed to facilitate seamless collaboration and productivity.

site_title: The rug connection
summary: Spanish industrial design graduate Nani Marquina has built a successful rug design company, nanimarquina, since founding it in 1987. Her rugs, designed to connect with people through colors and textures, are made from sustainable materials and produced in India, Pakistan, and Morocco using traditional techniques. Marquina collaborates with renowned designers and prioritizes fair labor practices, working with Care&Fair to fund local development projects. With a focus on handmade quality, her rugs are both aesthetically pleasing and environmentally conscious, with the company's mantra being "making people fall in love with our rugs".

site_title: Escalator sounds death knell for small HK shops
summary: In Hong Kong's Sai Ying Pun neighborhood, a new outdoor escalator has led to gentrification, pushing out small businesses and traditional eateries. The escalator, which opened last year, has attracted wealthier residents and expats, but has also driven up rents to HK$55-60 per square foot per month. As a result, many long-time shopkeepers and restaurant owners, such as Yeung Sun and Lee In-yu, are struggling to make ends meet, with some fearing they may have to close their businesses in as little as two years.

site_title: Albedo RTO deal still 'valid and binding'
summary: Albedo RTO deal with Infinite Rewards remains valid and binding despite a report that the deal was off. Representatives from Infinite Rewards, controlled by Malaysian tycoon Danny Tan, requested termination of the sale and purchase agreement, but no mutual agreement was reached. Albedo stated that neither party can unilaterally terminate the agreement, and the deal remains on track with a $1.9 billion value. The company's shares have more than doubled since the initial announcement.

site_title: Sanctions against Russia not the best way
summary: Western governments have imposed sanctions on Russia and Ukraine in response to Moscow's takeover of Crimea, but experts argue these sanctions may not be effective in deterring President Vladimir Putin from expanding his plans. Russia's strong economic ties with Europe, particularly in the energy sector, make it difficult to isolate economically without harming the global economy. The EU should prioritize encouraging a legitimate government in Ukraine, accelerating Ukraine's accession, and sending a stronger signal to Putin, rather than relying solely on economic sanctions.

site_title: Servcorp launches new serviced office at Metropolis Tower 2
summary: Servcorp is launching its fifth serviced office in Singapore, a 14,000 sq ft space at Metropolis Tower 2 in Buona Vista, offering 36 fully managed office suites and meeting rooms. The office will provide serviced facilities, including receptionist and ICT infrastructure, and will cater to companies seeking premium office space amid rising rents. Servcorp's CEO, Marcus Moufarrige, notes that serviced offices can be a cost-efficient alternative, saving clients 30-50% of traditional office space costs, with an average cost of $800 per person per month.

site_title: Electrical faults cause MAS plane to divert
summary: A Malaysia Airlines flight from Kuala Lumpur to Seoul, MH066, diverted to Hong Kong due to an inoperative aircraft generator on an Airbus A330-300, causing electrical power to be supplied by the Auxiliary Power Unit. The incident occurred early yesterday, adding to the carrier's ongoing issues with its missing plane crisis. No further details on the equipment problem were provided by the airline.

site_title: Neeraj Swaroop to helm StanChart S'pore
summary: Standard Chartered Bank Singapore is set to appoint Neeraj Swaroop as its new CEO, effective March 31. Swaroop's appointment aims to leverage growth opportunities in Asean, particularly in the Greater Mekong Subregion, which saw a 26% year-on-year increase in intra-Asean trade last year. The bank, which is 18% owned by Temasek Holdings, has a strong presence in Singapore, employing over 7,400 people and operating 19 branches. Swaroop replaces Ray Ferguson, who joined Bahrain-based Arab Banking Corporation, and will focus on maximizing opportunities in key growth regions.

site_title: Snapped up: Most of premium seats at Sports Hub stadium
summary: Most of the premium seats at Singapore's National Stadium, valued at $1,950 per year, have been pre-booked ahead of the stadium's opening, with over three-quarters of the 1,655 seats sold. The seats offer perks such as prime viewing positions, free parking, and access to exclusive club lounges. The World Sport Group expects the remaining seats to be taken up quickly as the stadium's event calendar grows, including the inaugural World Club 10s Rugby and a Causeway derby football match.

site_title: To be or not to be - an independent director?
summary: A growing number of people are considering taking on the role of an independent director, despite initial concerns about the responsibilities. Independent directorships can provide unique experiences and stimulate personal growth, but require caution due to enhanced corporate governance and potential legal liabilities. To become an effective independent director, prospective candidates should ask what they can contribute to the board, be independent and articulate, and avoid conflicts of interest. Starting with a smaller company and doing proper due diligence are also crucial. A directorship can be a fulfilling career achievement, especially for those seeking a challenge in turnaround processes.

site_title: Market rally to continue despite volatile sessions
summary: The US stock market is expected to continue its rally despite volatile sessions due to a strong outlook for corporate profits. Analysts at Morgan Stanley and Piper Jaffray predict a 13% gain for the Standard & Poor's 500 index in 2014, driven by improving economic data and low inflation. Volatility caused by the Crimean takeover and rising geopolitical uncertainty may persist, but analysts believe it will not significantly impact the market.

site_title: Lufthansa pilot pay spat highlights Iberia wage triumph
summary: Deutsche Lufthansa faces a pay dispute with its pilots, with demands for a double-digit pay hike and a strike ballot set to begin this week. In contrast, IAG, which includes Spanish unit Iberia, has successfully implemented pay cuts and cost reductions, resulting in increased investor credibility and earnings forecasts. IAG's operating profit is expected to reach 1.76 billion euros, while Lufthansa's earnings trail its own forecasts. The pay disparity highlights Lufthansa's challenge in delivering on earlier promises of savings and efficiencies, while IAG's success has led to a significant increase in its shares.

site_title: 2014: A transformative year for cloud computing
summary: In 2014, cloud computing experienced significant growth, with pace-setting organizations adopting mobile, social, analytics, and Big Data technologies. This year is expected to be transformative, with trends including interoperable clouds, delivery model evolution, and cloud ecosystem convergence. Key trends include the shift in the CIO's role from IT manager to cloud broker, the emergence of Cloud Foundry as a de-facto standard for platform-as-a-service, and the rise of industry-specific clouds. Additionally, mobile-first, cloud-delivered enterprise applications and real-time data analysis will become increasingly important, and cloud ecosystems will expand to deliver top-to-bottom solutions on open cloud platforms.

site_title: Basel III won't shift S'pore banks' focus on SMEs
summary: Singapore banks maintain support for small and medium enterprises (SMEs) despite the higher funding requirements under Basel III, a new regulatory framework. The increased capital requirements for lending to SMEs may lead to higher costs being passed on to the businesses, with SMEs having low bargaining power. However, key SME banks have been operating on risk-based models and the government has introduced a 70% risk-sharing program for microloans to improve financing. Despite this, some SMEs continue to face challenges in accessing funding from banks.

site_title: Ah, to be a suburban mall owner
summary: Suburban malls in Singapore, such as Junction 8 in Bishan, enjoy a durable competitive advantage due to their captive audience of nearby HDB dwellers and limited competition. With a diverse tenant mix catering to basic needs, these malls attract a constant stream of visitors. According to data, Junction 8 had a high occupancy rate of 99.4% in 2013, with net property income of $157 per square foot, making it one of the most profitable malls in Singapore. This model is sustainable due to the strong demand for shopping malls in Singapore, particularly for food and other basic needs.

site_title: Seized tanker with oil from rebel port reaches Tripoli
summary: A commercial oil tanker seized by US forces after loading crude at a rebel-held port in Libya has docked back in Tripoli. The tanker, Morning Glory, was taken off Cyprus after it left Es Sider port, controlled by rebels demanding more autonomy. The crew reported being forced to load crude and evade Libyan authorities. The tanker's cargo will be fed into the Zawiya refinery. The move is a rare victory for Tripoli, which is struggling to end a port blockade by rebels. Western governments are training Libya's armed forces and pressuring factions to reach a political settlement.

site_title: Bitcoin: virtual currency, real-world problems
summary: Bitcoin operators worldwide face real-world problems as they seek legitimacy and cooperation from financial institutions and authorities. In Singapore, the Monetary Authority of Singapore has proposed regulations to combat money laundering and terrorist financing, which some view as a step towards legitimacy. However, others fear this may lead to further regulation that could cripple the industry. The Bitcoin ecosystem is closely tied to the financial establishment, and its connection to banks and central authorities can be fragile. As the community seeks to establish itself, it must navigate the tension between its anarchist overtones and the need for cooperation with the financial system.

site_title: Data mining an increasingly useful tool in HR
summary: Data mining is increasingly being used in human resources to track employee growth, identify redundancies, and retain top talent. Companies like Akamai Technologies are leveraging big data to make informed hiring decisions and tailor performance management systems to individual employees' needs. With the talent crunch in the technology sector, firms are competing for the same skillsets, making data-driven insights crucial. By analyzing employee data, companies can identify areas for improvement and create custom models to ensure employee happiness and success.

site_title: Return of tanker glut leaves investors disillusioned
summary: Investors are losing optimism on oil-product tankers as a new glut of vessels threatens to further depress chartering rates. Despite initial expectations of rising demand due to US and Middle East exports, rates have fallen by a third, with some owners selling shares at below fleet value. Shipyards have ordered over 200 new vessels, but this has not led to material rate gains, with the backlog of new vessels creating a glut. As the fleet is expected to expand by 5.1% next year, meaningful rate increases are unlikely.

site_title: Tepid growth for banks in face of regulations
summary: Singapore banks face growth challenges due to Basel III regulations, which have increased acquisition costs and made it more expensive for banks to own overseas subsidiaries. The lucrative trade financing business is also a concern, as foreign banks with lower leverage ratios can compete more easily. Despite their strong credit ratings and cautious approach, mergers and acquisitions are being considered as a way to grow. Organic growth is also being prioritized, with banks adopting digital strategies to expand their footprint in growth markets. The easing of regulations has given foreign banks a competitive edge, and banks are waiting for the Monetary Authority of Singapore to finalize its consultation paper on the leverage ratio.

site_title: Delicious detour
summary: A chocolate-making class was held at the ChocoMuseo in Cuzco, Peru, where participants learned about the origin of cocoa beans and the process of making chocolate from scratch. The class included steps such as drying, grinding, mixing, and tempering, and students were able to create their own milk or bitter chocolate confections with different spices and flavorings. The class offered a unique and educational experience for those interested in chocolate and its production process.

site_title: Making a big splash in maritime
summary: BW Group, a global maritime outfit, has evolved from its bulk and tanker shipping heritage into a diversified oil and gas maritime enterprise. The company owns and operates a modern fleet of 110 offshore oil and gas vessels, including liquefied natural gas (LNG) carriers and floating production storage and offloading (FPSO) vessels. BW Group's CEO, Andreas Sohmen-Pao, aims to build up the company's core shipping fleet, expand its floating marine infrastructure, and invest in clean technologies. The company's IPO of its LPG shipping business was successful, with a market capitalization of 9.6 billion Norwegian kroner, and it is now exploring further listings.

site_title: No customer complaints over yuan-related products in Singapore: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has stated that it has not received any customer complaints regarding yuan-related products offered by financial institutions in Singapore. Retail deposits in yuan-denominated accounts make up a small portion of total yuan deposits, which reached $40.9 billion at the end of last year. MAS may review financial institutions' sales practices for investment products, and banks must assess customer knowledge and suitability, explain product features and risks, and implement safeguards to protect customers. This reflects the growing trade and investment ties between China and the region.

site_title: Rice to the occasion
summary: Yuichi Sato, a 32-year-old rice sommelier, brings premium Japanese rice to Singapore through his online delivery service, Tawaraya. Unlike other sommeliers, Sato sifts through paper sacks to differentiate between various rice grades and sources, including Hokkaido and Niigata. He sources rice from farms with minimal or no chemical use, resulting in better-tasting rice. With a steady clientele of 75 restaurants and 1,500 online customers, Sato aims to share the best of Japanese rice with Singaporeans, despite the high price point.

site_title: Numoni launches Malaysia's first bitcoin machines
summary: Singapore-based payment firm Numoni has launched Malaysia's first bitcoin vending machines in Kuala Lumpur's Bangsar Shopping Centre and Penang's Gurney Plaza. The machines, priced at US$4,500, enable users to buy small amounts of bitcoin, a cryptocurrency seen as an international voucher. Numoni plans to install 10 machines in Malaysia within a year and 100 over three years, with BTC Future Sdn Bhd as the distributor. The move follows Numoni's launch of bitcoin vending machines in Singapore earlier this year, with plans for a touchscreen model launching in September.

site_title: SIA, Hoe Leong lead week's buybacks
summary: In the third week of March, Singapore Exchange filings showed a rebound in buying activity, with 35 purchases worth $3.12 million, outnumbering disposals worth $131,000. Hoe Leong Corporation, a vessel-chartering services provider, made its first buyback in nearly two years, purchasing 82,000 shares at 12.4 cents each. Singapore Airlines also bought back shares, with 1.069 million shares purchased from March 13 to 20 at an average of $10.20 each. Other companies with insider buys included Ho Bee Land, Best World International, Fragrance Group, Tat Hong Holdings, Ying Li Real Estate, and PSL Holdings.

site_title: Ascott Reit buys Japan property for 6.3b yen
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (Ascott Reit) has acquired Infini Garden in Fukuoka, Japan, for 6.3 billion yen (S$78.4 million). The 389-unit property is the Reit's second acquisition in Fukuoka and its second property in Japan, with an expected Ebitda yield of 6.6%. The acquisition is expected to raise the Reit's FY2013 distribution per unit to 8.58 cents, enhancing its income stability and competitive positioning.

site_title: DBS eyes higher growth from SME segment
summary: DBS Group expects its income growth from the small and medium enterprises (SME) segment to outpace last year's 10% growth, with a focus on emerging markets. The bank aims to increase its income from these markets to one-third of the sector's income. Despite some headwinds, including loan losses, DBS is pushing for disciplined growth and has launched a digital strategy to expand its footprint. The bank's NPL rate stands at 1.1%, and it has seen strong growth in Hong Kong and Singapore, driven by Chinese companies taking advantage of cheaper offshore lending rates.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Banks face challenges due to Basel III regulations, while Temasek Holdings returns profits to the community. New satellite images suggest possible debris from the missing Malaysian airliner in the Indian Ocean. BW Group Ltd. makes a big splash in the maritime industry, while Albedo RTO deal is still valid. MISC Bhd's logistics sale is seen as beneficial for the company, and the NSA has hacked Huawei's servers. ABN Amro eyes relisting as a safe, local bank, and the US-Japan-S Korea summit aims to cool regional tensions. Bombardier suspends Russian plane plans due to sanctions.

site_title: Profits earned by Temasek 'are returned to community'
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singapore-based investment company, celebrates its 40th anniversary with a focus on long-term growth and community involvement. Chairman Lim Boon Heng emphasizes the company's commitment to returning profits to the community, citing examples of philanthropic efforts such as the Temasek Foundation and Temasek Cares. Temasek has a $215 billion portfolio and has set aside $1.5 billion for non-profit philanthropic organizations, including a new $40 million emergency preparedness fund.

site_title: Tech Mahindra looks to grow in Asia-Pacific
summary: Indian IT firm Tech Mahindra reports better-than-expected third-quarter financial results, with revenue up 17.2% year-over-year to $791 million and profit after tax up 175.7% to $163.1 million. The company aims to grow in the Asia-Pacific region, with a focus on the region contributing around 23% of its global revenues. Tech Mahindra's senior VP Rohit Gandhi outlines a three-pronged strategy to accelerate growth, including offering solutions based on its NMACS Way, concentrating on existing verticals, and building up presence in new verticals such as healthcare and retail.

site_title: S'pore banks: tougher rules boon for confidence
summary: Singapore banks support stricter regulatory requirements, with a minimum common equity Tier 1 capital adequacy ratio of 9% and strict adherence to Basel III standards. This approach aims to maintain greater depositor, customer, and market confidence in the financial sector, reducing the likelihood of costly crises. However, the implementation of these regulations poses challenges, including higher data management costs and the need for banks to process complex data on OTC derivative trades. Despite these challenges, Singapore's regulatory framework remains robust and nimble, allowing it to remain competitive with other jurisdictions.

site_title: Bombardier suspends Russian plans in wake of sanctions
summary: Bombardier Inc. has suspended its plans to build planes in Russia and sell US$3.4 billion of aircraft due to Canada's imposition of sanctions against Russia. The Montreal-based company had signed a deal to sell turboprop aircraft to Russia's state-owned Rostekhnologii and establish a turboprop assembly line. CEO Pierre Beaudoin stated that the delay will be due to the uncertainty surrounding the sanctions. This decision comes as Canada joins the US in imposing sanctions against Russia following its annexation of Crimea.

images.alt_text: On hold: Bombardier had signed a letter of intent in August to sell Russia's Rostekhnologii as many as 100 Q400 turboprop aircraft (above). - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: Thai court declares Feb elections void
summary: Thailand's Constitutional Court has declared February's election void due to the failure of voting in 28 districts blocked by protesters, violating the Constitution. The ruling delays the formation of a new government, which has been paralyzed by months of street protests. The court has given the country two options to organize a new vote, but protesters have vowed to disrupt any future election. The ruling further exacerbates an eight-year crisis pitting Bangkok's middle class against supporters of Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra.

site_title: Spanish chef in his Element
summary: Spanish chef Mikel Badiola has opened a new restaurant at Amara Singapore, serving authentic Basque cuisine with a focus on homespun flavors. The all-day-dining concept offers a generous buffet, but the chef's authentic pintxos and a la carte menu are the highlights. Standout dishes include croquetas, piquillo peppers, and Spanish tortilla, while the roast suckling pig is a showstopper. Minor quibbles aside, the restaurant is a must-visit for foodies, with a unique blend of Spanish and Asian flavors. Chef Badiola's menu is a refreshing change from the usual hotel dining experience.

site_title: How can a plane vanish in a small world?
summary: A Malaysia Airlines Boeing 777, flight MH370, vanished from electronic sight during a routine flight in March 2014, defying modern aviation's reliance on numerous onboard systems and tracking arrangements. Despite extensive global cooperation and technical expertise, the cause of the disappearance remains unknown, with experts citing the limitations of human knowledge and the complexity of modern systems. The incident is a rare exception to the rule that technological breakdowns can be identified and prevented, and it may lead to new equipment, tighter supervision, or improved rules.

site_title: At home in the Range
summary: The Range Rover Sport SDV6 is a family-friendly SUV with a lightweight aluminium body and permanent four-wheel-drive air suspension, offering a surprising engaging drive despite its size. It shares the same platform as the more expensive Range Rover, but has a sportier styling, more power, and a firmer electronic air suspension. The vehicle features a luxurious interior, seven standard seats, and a low-noise turbodiesel engine, making it a classy alternative to an MPV.

site_title: Hotel Royal to acquire Phuket's Burasari Resort
summary: Hotel Royal Limited is acquiring Phuket's Burasari Resort for approximately $51 million. The four-star property, with 186 rooms, is situated near Patong beach and will be acquired through the purchase of Panali Company Limited's entire share capital by Hotel Royal's subsidiaries. The acquisition is seen as an opportunity to expand Hotel Royal's hotel operations in the region, with the group expecting added synergy in sales referrals and joint marketing efforts. The deal is expected to be completed by June 30.

site_title: Unionmet's rights: poser over irrevocable undertaking
summary: Unionmet, a Chinese indium supplier, released its rights issue results, showing only 18.44% of the 306.8 million shares subscribed, far short of the target. Despite a substantial shareholder, Weng Huixin, having given an irrevocable undertaking to take up its rights entitlement, no mention was made of Ms. Weng's portion or how the proceeds would be divided. The company's shares ended 0.1 cent higher at 6 cents, sparking concerns among dealers about the validity of the undertaking and its impact on ordinary shareholders.

site_title: New circle of life
summary: The Limited Edition Concepts (LEC) group, led by Godwin Pereira and Ross Glasscoe, has transformed a 400m stretch of Circular Road in Singapore into a vibrant entertainment and dining destination. The $8 million deal to acquire 28 shophouses has been completed, with the first phase focusing on relocating The Vault nightclub and opening new concepts such as Le Comptoir, Chateaux, and Hero's. The second phase will introduce French winebar and creperie, upscale ultralounge, and live music and sports bar. The fourth phase, set to begin by July, will feature outdoor events and fashion shows.

site_title: Making room for work
summary: Co-working spaces are expanding to cater to local artisans and makers, offering unique spaces for hands-on work. Mettle Work, a space in Geylang, provides rooms with wooden sliding doors, cement floors, and industrial chic decor, suitable for makers, craft folks, and artists. Rent starts at $399/month. Another co-working space, Keong Saik Collab, offers a mix of tech, design, and entrepreneurship, with a focus on collaboration and community. Kitchen Lab 1, a commercial kitchen space, allows users to rent a licensed kitchen for food businesses, with rates starting from $9/off-peak hours. These spaces aim to provide affordable and accessible options for local entrepreneurs and makers.

site_title: Two career tracks in S'pore Legal Service
summary: Singapore's Legal Service is undergoing a change with the introduction of two career tracks, the judicial track and the legal track, starting in April. This move aims to provide greater specialisation and expertise for Legal Service Officers, addressing the growing need for specialist skills. The change was announced by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong after discussions with key officials, including the Chief Justice, Attorney-General, and Minister for Law.

site_title: Temasek pays US$5.7b for quarter of Watson
summary: Temasek Holdings has acquired a 24.95% stake in Li Ka-shing's AS Watson, the world's largest international health and beauty retailer, for US$5.7 billion. The deal confirms that a public offering of AS Watson shares, including Temasek's newly acquired stake, is still on the cards. Despite initial reports suggesting the move would scupper AS Watson's listing plans, Temasek and Hutchison Whampoa, AS Watson's parent, have agreed to work together towards a suitable listing time. The acquisition increases Temasek's exposure to the consumer retail sector, particularly in growing Asia.

site_title: Blackstone may sell industrial building in Ubi: report
summary: Blackstone Group, the world's largest alternative asset manager, is considering the sale of its industrial building in Singapore, StarHub Green, due to StarHub's recent lease extension. The building, acquired in 2012 for S$215 million, is now valued higher due to the lease renewal. Other tenants include Boustead Singapore and Quest Laboratories. Blackstone's decision comes as rents for industrial properties rose 5% in the quarter ended Dec 31. The company has also invested US$7 billion in Asia since its first deal in 2007, and recently opened an office in Singapore.

site_title: Russia sanctions will have wider impact than its targets: bankers
summary: US and European sanctions against Russia are having a ripple effect, with Visa and MasterCard halting payment services for a bank linked to US blacklist targets. Banks are cautious about doing business with anyone linked to the blacklist, fearing broader measures that could choke off international payments and trade. Germany's main trade body warned that full-blown economic sanctions would be a "real catastrophe." Foreign bankers in Russia say things would have to deteriorate further before they reconsider their investments. The sanctions have already led to the sale of a Russian billionaire's stake in an oil trader and forced state-owned banks to repatriate funds.

site_title: Hard truths in the lens at film fest
summary: The Southeast Asian Film Festival, now in its fourth year, will showcase regional politics and identity through 20 films, including documentaries and feature films. The festival, held at the Singapore Art Museum, will highlight grim issues such as communities living through instability and hardship. Notable films include "The Act of Killing" and "Pascalina", with a special focus on Mindanao, Philippines, and experimental filmmaking techniques. The festival runs from April 11 to May 4, with post-screening discussions and a range of ticket options available.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Financial markets worldwide retreated as the US Federal Reserve hinted at a more hawkish stance, with interest rate hikes possible in 2015. The Singapore dollar fell 1% after the announcement. Petrochemical margins are expected to remain under pressure and volatile. Meanwhile, Tiger Airways completed the sale of a 40% stake in its Philippine unit to Cebu Pacific. In Singapore, the Legal Service will introduce two career paths for LSOs in April, and Boat Quay will undergo a makeover. Malaysia is well-prepared to weather financial storms, while China's banks face challenges from Alibaba's Yu E Bao.

site_title: Asia-Pac M&A Q1 deals up 22% at US$112.7b
summary: Asia-Pacific mergers and acquisitions (M&A) deals reached $112.7 billion in Q1 2014, a 22% increase from the previous year. Real estate accounted for nearly a quarter of the activity, with China companies being the target of $39.1 billion in deals. Singapore companies attracted $12 billion, while completed deals totaled $55 billion, the lowest first-quarter level since 2009. M&A advisory fees decreased 23.4% compared to the previous year, with Goldman Sachs taking the top spot with $35.5 million in fees.

site_title: All but one US top bank pass Fed stress test
summary: The Federal Reserve's annual stress tests found 29 of the 30 largest US banks can withstand a deep recession, with only Zions Bancorporation falling below one of the central bank's main capital thresholds. The test, required under the Dodd-Frank Act, simulated a severe economic slump and rising interest rates, with total projected loan losses differing widely between scenarios. Regulators will judge whether banks' management actions, such as dividend cuts, keep them above the minimum Tier 1 common ratio of 5% over nine quarters in harsh economic scenarios, which may affect payouts next week.

site_title: Mapletree Ind to develop build-to-suit facility for HP
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) will develop a new build-to-suit facility for Hewlett-Packard Singapore at its Telok Blangah Cluster property. The $250 million project will unlock portfolio value, maximize plot ratio, and grow MIT's high-tech segment. The redeveloped facility will include two new buildings with a total gross floor area of 824,500 sq ft, leased for 10.5 years with annual rent escalations. The project is expected to be completed in the first half of 2017, subject to approval from relevant authorities.

site_title: SRX launches real-time property pricing feature
