summary: The Singapore Real Estate Exchange (SRX) has launched a real-time property pricing feature called "X-Value" to mitigate problems faced by HDB home buyers. X-Value provides an algorithmically derived price based on past transacted prices of comparable units, adjusted for factors such as size, location, and amenities. The feature aims to provide a standard for pricing homes and assist pre-valuation financing decisions, giving buyers and sellers more clarity in the HDB resale market.

site_title: Market ends flat after strenuous week
summary: The Singapore stock market ended flat on Friday, March 21, 2014, with the Straits Times Index (STI) registering a 0.33-point loss to 3,073.39. The week saw several market-moving events, including a China property firm's bond default, tensions in Ukraine, and negative news affecting Johor property play Albedo Investment. The US Federal Open Market Committee meeting also raised interest rate concerns, with the Federal Reserve hinting at sooner-than-expected rate hikes.

site_title: Masterful Macan
summary: The Porsche Macan S is a luxury compact SUV with superior on-road handling compared to the Audi SQ5. The Macan S features a 3.0-litre V6 twin turbo engine, producing 340 hp and 460 Nm, and a softer suspension tuning for better composure in sweeping curves. It also boasts a permanent all-wheel-drive system with PTM Porsche Traction Management and an off-road mode, allowing it to traverse muddy roads and steep inclines with ease. The Macan S is priced from $258,888, competing with the Macan Turbo, which has a similar engine but more equipment and a heavier weight.

site_title: OW Bunker plans Copenhagen IPO of up to 5.5b kroner
summary: OW Bunker, a Danish ship fuel supplier, plans to list its shares on the Copenhagen stock market with an initial public offering (IPO) of up to 5.5 billion kroner. The company aims to raise 110 million kroner to pay down debt and is expected to float between 40-60% of its shares. The IPO, coordinated by Carnegie and Morgan Stanley, is part of Europe's growing new issues market, which has seen a significant increase in IPO activity this year.

site_title: When opposite opinions are both right
summary: A recent study found that coronary angiography, the gold standard for testing blocked heart arteries, can provide conflicting results due to its limitations. The test only provides a two-dimensional view of the lumen and doesn't visualize the artery wall, leading to potential misinterpretations. This can result in differing opinions among experts, with one in eight patients being reassessed as having less severe blockage than initially thought. The study highlights the need for further advances in assessing heart artery disease to better identify patients who will benefit from treatment.

site_title: Hermes still king in luxury market
summary: Hermès International reported a 7% increase in net profit to 790 million euros in 2013, driven by double-digit sales growth in the US and Asia. The luxury brand attributed its success to a shift in the Chinese market towards a more mature luxury culture, favoring understated designs over flashy logos. Hermès' revenue rose 7.8% to 3.8 billion euros, tempered by currency weakness in its main overseas markets. The company's CEO, Axel Dumas, said the company has not seen an impact on its finances in China, but acknowledged the potential for an impact in an economic downturn.

site_title: Bulgari's Indian seduction
summary: Bulgari's Omnia Indian Garnet fragrance is the latest addition to the luxury brand's fragrance line, inspired by the colors and senses of India. Master perfumer Alberto Morillas created the scent, which features a precious mandarin garnet and tuberose, an Indian mythical flower, to evoke the country's sumptuousness and femininity. The fragrance is part of Bulgari's successful Omnia range, which contributes 23-25% of the brand's total annual revenue, and is set to launch in May at $49-$134 for various products.

site_title: Bordeaux's many splendours
summary: Burgundy wine prices have skyrocketed, making Bordeaux wines more accessible. Demand from mainland China and a limited supply have driven up prices, with some bottles reaching HK$150,000 (S$25,000) for a 1990 Romanee Conti. However, Bordeaux remains a more affordable option for wine lovers. The author revisits Bordeaux, finding great enjoyment and satisfaction in wines like Chateau Latour 2002 and Chateau Pontet Canet, which are now drinking well and offer good value. Bordeaux's consistent quality and approachability make it a reliable choice for wine enthusiasts.

site_title: Business briefing
summary: China Huiyuan Juice Group will issue US$150 million worth of convertible bonds to Temasek Holdings' unit Baytree Investments (Mauritius), with Temasek holding 7.68% of Huiyuan's enlarged share capital upon full conversion.

site_title: Off the beaten track
summary: Travelers can explore the world's largest salt flats in Bolivia, featuring stunning desert landscapes, surrealistic volcanic rocks, and wildlife-like pink flamingos. The area is also home to the Tayka hotel network, offering luxe accommodations. Nearby, San Pedro de Atacama, Chile, is a hub for hippie-chic tourism, with preserved adobe architecture, restaurants, and artisanal shops. Chile's Patagonia region, including Torres del Paine National Park, offers breathtaking mountain views, glaciers, and hiking trails, with luxury hotels and refugios available.

site_title: No child's play at cult anime studio
summary: Studio Ghibli's latest film, The Wind Rises, has earned nominations for Best Foreign Film and Best Animated Film at the Golden Globe and Oscars. Despite controversy over its World War II theme, the film has received critical acclaim and was Japan's top-grossing movie of 2013. The studio's International Division defends the film, stating that criticisms were raised by those who haven't seen it. Ghibli has a strict no-edits policy for overseas markets, and the English version features a new voice cast while maintaining the original director's vision.

site_title: Must-sees from the Argillet collection
summary: Artist Robert Rauschenberg experimented with unusual tools in his mixed media prints, including chisels and acid-etched octopus heads, from 1963-1965. The 16 prints showcased his innovative approach to art.

site_title: SGX commodity derivatives trade soars 70%
summary: SGX's commodity derivatives trade surged 70% in 2013, outpacing global growth of 23%. The exchange recorded 1,006,807 lots traded, with six products experiencing growth and one decline. OTC Iron Ore saw the largest growth, with a 278% increase, while OTC Rubber grew 278%. The exchange attributes the growth to high derivative clearing fees and partnerships with Chinese exchanges.

site_title: More S'pore-issued Basel III bonds in the offing: Moody's
summary: Singapore banks are expected to issue more Basel III compliant securities, with about 25% of their Basel II securities callable this year. These new securities will absorb losses when the banks are in distress, making them credit-positive for local depositors and senior bondholders. Moody's expects banks to replace "old-style" securities with new Basel III compliant ones, with over $3 billion worth of such instruments already issued by Singapore banks.

site_title: Swinging in the Philippines
summary: The Philippines boasts Asia's oldest national golf championship, the Philippine Open, first played in 1913. The country is home to numerous superbly challenging first-class golf courses, including Anvaya Cove Golf & Sports Club, Ayala Greenfield Golf & Leisure Club, and Wack Wack Golf & Country Club. Designed by renowned architects, these courses offer breathtaking views, water hazards, and challenging layouts. With various facilities and accommodations available, golf enthusiasts can enjoy a luxurious experience in the country. The best time to visit is from November to February, and major airlines fly to Manila's Ninoy Aquino International Airport and Clark International Airport.

site_title: Old optical shop's new vision
summary: Kwang Meng, an optical lens manufacturer, has joined forces with Pin Pin Optical Store in a joint venture, preserving the iconic brand after it almost closed down three years ago. The partnership allows Kwang Meng to gain insight into the retail sector and develop new products, while Pin Pin gains new equipment, practices, and products. The company aims to create an "open" market for frame selection, where customers can browse freely, and has tested the concept in their warehouse store. The partnership is seen as a win for Singapore's optical retail scene, saving a beloved brand from extinction.

site_title: Fed may raise rates by next spring: Yellen
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen hinted at a more aggressive path towards higher interest rates, potentially raising rates by next spring. The Fed will end its massive bond-buying program this autumn, and Yellen suggested rates could rise around six months later. This shift in guidance sent stocks and bonds tumbling, with economists predicting the first rate hike in the second half of 2015. Yellen emphasized that rates will remain low for a while and rise gradually, but the Fed will consider inflation and unemployment rates to determine the timing of rate hikes.

site_title: Jamie Oliver visit has fans out in full force
summary: Jamie Oliver, a British celebrity chef, made a highly anticipated visit to Singapore, marking his first public visit to his eight-month-old restaurant, Jamie's Italian Singapore at Vivocity. He met with his local team, took pictures, and autographed cookbooks for over 200 fans. After a visit to Maxwell Market to try local dishes, Oliver departed for Perth, Australia, to launch his Ministry of Food Australia programme, aiming to inspire inexperienced cooks to make meals from scratch.

site_title: Exit from QE policies 'fraught with risk'
summary: The US Federal Reserve's decision to further taper its securities purchases has raised concerns about the potential fallout on bond markets, particularly in emerging East Asia. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) warned of possible "contagion" effects, while a prominent economist in Japan, Richard Koo, predicted that exit from quantitative easing policies could provoke crises. The Fed's move to scale back bond purchases by $10 billion per month is seen as a sign that US interest rates could rise sharply from historic lows, posing risks to central bank balance sheets and financial markets.

site_title: Private equity funds move into maritime industry
summary: Private equity funds have rapidly entered the maritime industry, driven by the slowdown in bank lending. However, industry players believe this trend does not signal a long-term shift in financing. While PE funds are investing in shipping, their involvement is relatively low, and they are taking a calculated approach, scrutinizing projects before investing. Analysts doubt that PE firms will become long-term shipowners, as they prioritize asset appreciation and exit strategies over long-term returns, which the shipping sector offers. This may limit the influx of private equity capital into the industry.

site_title: Transpac lines agree to up freight rates earlier
summary: Transpacific Stabilization Agreement (TSA) has agreed to raise Asia-US freight rates by $300 per 40-foot container from April 15, reversing earlier declines. The decision, made by 15 major container shipping lines, aims to correct market conditions and reflects the improving cargo picture eastbound from Asia. This is the third rate increase, following January 15 and March 15, amid concerns that rates had plunged to loss-making levels in 2013 due to overcapacity.

site_title: Vision Exchange: first phase sale tomorrow
summary: Sim Lian Group launches the first phase of its integrated development, Vision Exchange, for sale tomorrow. Located in Jurong East, the 99-year leasehold commercial property will feature a 25-storey office tower, F&B space, and medical suites. The first phase will release 250 units, with average prices of $2,150 psf for office units and $4,498 psf for medical suites and F&B units. The development is expected to be completed in 2018 and is targeted at businesses and investors seeking a prime location with access to a large resident catchment population.

site_title: Private placement by Suntec raises questions
summary: Suntec Reit raised $350 million through a private placement to repay debt, diluting minority investors. The placement, which was not for growth purposes, was done at a time when Suntec's shares were trading at a four-month high, making it a less favorable time for retail investors. The move is expected to lead to lower distributions per unit and may impact minority investors' yields, which could be a concern for retirees relying on Reits for income.

site_title: A continent of delights
summary: Peru is a top destination for foodies, boasting a unique blend of local cuisine and gourmet dining. Machu Picchu, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, is a must-visit, with its rich history and stunning natural surroundings. The country's dining scene is led by renowned chefs like Gaston Acurio and Virgilio Martinez, with restaurants like Central, Astrid & Gaston, and Madam Tusan's offering exceptional fine dining experiences. From ceviche to traditional dishes like cuy, Peruvian cuisine is a fusion of local flavors and innovative techniques. Visitors can explore the charming town of Cuzco, a former Inca capital, and acclimatize to the high altitude before visiting Machu Picchu.

site_title: Petrochemical margins squeezed; volatility seen
summary: Petrochemical margins are expected to remain under pressure and be volatile in 2014 due to new capacity additions and high demand for petrochemicals. Petrochemical Corporation of Singapore (PCS) plans to improve energy efficiency and reduce utilities costs, and is also investing in a butadiene plant expansion to support new synthetic rubber plants. PCS managing director Akira Yonemura warned of challenges ahead in maintaining plant integrity and reliability with ageing plants, and expects petrochemical margins to remain under pressure despite improving demand.

site_title: Holding court with basketball's goliaths
summary: Veteran television actor Tay Ping Hui's directorial debut, "Meeting The Giant," features a basketball team from Singapore competing against foreign talent. Tay cast local basketball team members in key roles to ensure authenticity, citing the importance of real players over experienced actors. The film, set in the early 2000s, explores the challenges of competition between locals and foreigners, but is not a political commentary, according to Tay. The movie aims to represent both Singaporean and Chinese perspectives fairly and break into the China market.

site_title: Sommelier's dream pairing with Thai fare
summary: Restaurant owner Joel Low, a former sommelier, has transformed his 14-year-old Thai eatery, Jane Thai, in Orchard Towers by introducing a mookata concept and repainting the walls. The business now generates $1,200 in daily sales, up from $500, and profits are being reinvested. Low, 27, had put his wine career on hold to acquire the restaurant, which he plans to expand into four more hawker stalls. He hosts wine pairing tastings with Thai food, and the restaurant has become a conversation starter, attracting a diverse customer base.

site_title: Tiger completes sale of stake in Philippine unit
summary: Budget carrier Tiger Airways completed the sale of a 40% stake in its Philippine unit, Tigerair Philippines, to Cebu Pacific for $7 million. The deal allows Cebu Pacific to expand its network to Australia and India, while Tiger Airways will leverage Cebu Pacific's network in the Philippines and North Asia. The two carriers will form a strategic alliance, increasing flight frequencies and jointly selling routes, as part of an interline agreement.

site_title: Unscripted and left to chance
summary: Singaporean playwright Irfan Kasban is staging an experimental production, A Beautiful Chance Encounter of a Sewing Machine and an Umbrella on an Operating Table, where actors will perform individual narratives without prior rehearsals, guided only by chance encounters. The one-and-a-half-hour production will run from March 27 to 29 at an open field, with no intellectual discourse or predetermined plot. Kasban aims to challenge the intellectual and insular nature of the Singapore theatre scene, encouraging audiences to simply enjoy the performance. Admission is free.

site_title: Young blood, old trades
summary: A 29-year-old entrepreneur, Jonathan Chiang, has revived a 40-year-old tailor shop, Leong Tailors, in Singapore's upscale Keong Saik Road. Chiang, who has a passion for fine details, has updated the traditional business with a modern twist, offering bespoke tailoring services, shoeshine, and accessories. Despite the challenges of competing with off-the-shelf brands, Chiang aims to establish a year-long pop-up shop that will eventually become Singapore's first men-focused emporium, featuring local designers and a gentlemen's lounge.

site_title: Heartwarming road trip
summary: The Journey, a Malaysian film, has become the country's top-grossing movie of all time with RM17 million earnings. The movie tells the story of an English man, Benji, who travels with his father-in-law, Chuan, across Malaysia to deliver wedding invites, bridging their cultural differences and softening Chuan's heart. The film's heartwarming drama and light-hearted comedy capture everyday Malaysian life, despite some predictable plot points and minor flaws. Despite its imperfections, the film's charm and authenticity make it a worthwhile watch.

site_title: Iron Lady clad in lace lets rip with histrionics
summary: A theatrical production of Federico Garcia Lorca's "The House of Bernarda Alba" by Wild Rice Theatre was staged with a stellar cast and aesthetically designed elements. Directed by Glen Goei, the play explores themes of universality and relevance to societies critiqued by Lorca. The production features a strong female cast, including Claire Wong as the controlling matriarch and Glory Ngim as the youngest, most tempestuous sister. While the play's "stage noir" feel and choreographed movements impressed, the reviewer found the drama and histrionics to be overwhelming at times, detracting from the immersive experience. The production runs until March 29.

images.alt_text: Women power: Claire Wong, who plays Bernarda, leading a strong cast of veterans such as Neo Swee Lin, Karen Tan and Jo Kukathas in Federico Garcia Lorca's The House of Bernarda Alba. - PHOTO: WILD RICE

site_title: Unearthing ties that bind us to Nature
summary: The Singapore Art Museum's "Unearthed" exhibition explores the relationship between nature and culture, particularly in the context of climate change in Singapore. The show features 22 local artworks, including photography, installation, and video, examining the human connection to nature. The exhibition highlights the impact of climate change on Singapore's natural sites, such as the Bukit Brown cemetery, and aims to spark conversations about the interconnectedness of art, nature, and everyday life. The show runs until July 6 at the Singapore Art Museum and SAM at 8Q, with free admission for Singapore citizens and children under six.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: CCM Group's Shenton Way contract has been terminated due to alleged breaches by 70 Shenton Pte Ltd. Yoma Strategic Holdings has set up two new subsidiaries in Myanmar, while Tritech Group's unit won a 24.36 million yuan contract for a waste water treatment plant. Vallianz Holdings established a $500 million debt issuance programme for general corporate purposes.

site_title: Boeing 787 Dreamliner safe to fly: FAA review
summary: The Boeing 787 Dreamliner has been deemed safe to fly by the FAA after a joint review, which found the plane's design and safety processes to be sound. The review was initiated after a battery fire in 2013, but also identified issues with Boeing's manufacturing process and the FAA's oversight. The FAA and Boeing have implemented recommendations to address these issues, with Boeing already taking steps to improve its processes. However, concerns remain about the impact of cost-cutting measures on future programs, such as the 777-X aircraft.

site_title: Suppliers of jet parts require greater oversight: report
summary: Federal regulators need to provide greater oversight of the supply networks for modern commercial planes, according to a report by the Federal Aviation Administration and Boeing. The report, released after the 787 Dreamliner jet's four-month grounding due to lithium-ion battery issues, found that Boeing's design safety is met, but regulators must adapt to the changing industry. The agency is shifting its review process to focus on suppliers and monitoring their quality-control measures, and Boeing has acknowledged failing to monitor suppliers closely early in the project.

site_title: A small step back to normal for Bangkok
summary: Bangkok has lifted its state of emergency, but the city remains uncertain due to ongoing protests and violence. The move offers hope to businesses and investors, but the situation is still volatile, with the Internal Security Act in place until April. Thailand's economy has suffered, losing over $3 billion, and further unrest could lead to recession. The government predicts a 2-3% GDP growth if violence subsides, but warns of flat or negative growth if the conflict continues. Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra must find a way to end the conflict soon to avoid missing out on lucrative economic opportunities.

site_title: Crunching numbers at his own stall
summary: A 31-year-old Singaporean, Ryan Chua, left his job as a risk analyst at DBS Bank to take over his parents' hawker stall in Jurong East, selling pork rib soup. Chua worked weekends for six months to perfect the family recipe, with his parents' supervision. He now manages the stall, applying his finance training to improve workflow and efficiency. Despite facing challenges, Chua aims to expand the business and open a standalone shop, with plans to increase staff to alleviate bottlenecks in the kitchen.

site_title: Osborne's shrewd Budget has 2015 election in mind
summary: British Chancellor George Osborne has released a shrewd Budget targeting baby-boomers ahead of the 2015 General Election. The budget includes incentives for corporate investment and exports, a revamped pension system, and increased tax relief for companies investing in new equipment. The government aims to reduce unemployment and keep potential voters happy, while continuing to reduce the budget deficit. Osborne also announced plans to cap energy costs and increase infrastructure spending, despite concerns that the UK's growth is unbalanced and highly weighted towards the property boom.

site_title: Sepia-tinged caper
summary: Wes Anderson's "The Grand Budapest Hotel" is a visually stunning and quirky film set in 1930s Europe, blending offbeat charm and unique visual style. The story follows Gustave H, a concierge with a meticulous style, as he navigates a complex caper involving murder, theft, and a priceless painting. With a star-studded cast, including Ralph Fiennes, Tilda Swinton, and Willem Dafoe, the film is a comedic romp with an element of tragedy, inspired by the writings of Stefan Zweig. The film's unconventional approach and memorable performances make it an enchanting, if not substantial, cinematic experience.

site_title: Stones rock the house
summary: The Rolling Stones performed a sold-out concert in Singapore, with Mick Jagger and 70-year-old bandmates Keith Richards, Charlie Watts, and Ronnie Wood delivering a high-energy show. The concert, held at the Marina Bay Sands, featured 18 classic songs and a memorable encore. However, the evening was cut short two days later with the news of Jagger's long-time girlfriend, L'Wren Scott, who died by suicide. The incident led to the indefinite postponement of the rest of the Stones' tour in Australia and New Zealand.

site_title: Growing up with Dali
summary: Salvador Dali, the renowned surrealist artist, was often portrayed as eccentric in the media, but Christine Argillet, who spent summers with Dali as a child, reveals a more down-to-earth individual who was shy and sought opinions on his art. Argillet's father, Pierre, collaborated with Dali on nearly 200 etchings and was his publisher until 1974. A collection of these etchings, along with rare tapestries, is now on display at the Redsea Gallery in Singapore, offering a rare glimpse into Dali's life and work.

site_title: Around Town
summary: Singapore's National Museum is hosting "The People's Collection," a six-part television series showcasing national heritage items collected from various locations, until April 29, 2014. Meanwhile, local artist Justin Y's solo exhibition "The Circle of Life" features abstract finger paintings until April 6. Disney On Ice: Treasure Trove is running at the Singapore Indoor Stadium until March 23, with various showtimes. Additionally, "Traces" will be performed by NUS Dance Synergy and Re: Dance Theatre on March 22, and "Hit The Roof" is a pop-up event promoting urban farming at the People's Park Complex on March 23.

site_title: Getting between the Covers
summary: Artist Heman Chong, 37, has gained recognition for his series of imagined book covers, which have sold out at each exhibition since 2009. The series, "Of Indeterminate Time or Occurrence," has supported Chong as a full-time artist, with 338 paintings to date. His unique approach, blending abstraction and literary references, has resonated with collectors, who appreciate the series' modularity and intellectual appeal. Chong's graphic art background and instinctive color choices contribute to the series' success, with prices ranging from $5,000 per piece.

site_title: Luxury home project in Johor in the works
summary: China's Country Garden Holdings Co Ltd and Kumpulan Prasarana Rakyat Johor (KPRJ) are collaborating on a massive reclamation project to build Forest City, a luxury home development near Second Link in southern Johor, Malaysia. The project, estimated to cover a few thousand acres, is expected to be one of Iskandar Malaysia's largest single projects, dwarfing Country Garden's previous 50-acre project in Danga Bay. The joint venture is backed by Country Garden's substantial cash reserves and KPRJ's government investment arm.

site_title: Zombie races get the adrenaline pumping
summary: Singapore's zombie-themed running events, such as Run For Your Lives and Race the Dead, have gained popularity, drawing up to 10,000 participants per event. Organizers, like Infinitus and Celebrity Trainer, invest significant resources to ensure safety and unique experiences, with some events costing over $1 million to execute. As the industry becomes saturated, some predict the trend will fade, while others plan to franchise their concepts regionally and take them overseas.

site_title: Livewires sex up the classics
summary: Il Divo, a classical crossover vocal group managed by Simon Cowell, performed in Singapore as part of their 10th anniversary celebration and A Musical Affair world tour. The group, consisting of Swiss tenor Urs Buhler, Spanish baritone Carlos Marin, French pop star Sébastien Izambard, and American tenor David Miller, delivered note-perfect renditions of their showstoppers, including Rodgers & Hammerstein's "You'll Never Walk Alone." However, their pop tunes were often overpowered, and the group's cheeky stage banter and playful jabs at their audience proved more entertaining than the music itself.

site_title: Feting Mandela's triumphs
summary: Nelson Mandela's life was immortalized in the film "Mandela: Long Walk to Freedom," directed by Justin Chadwick and written by William Nicholson. The movie chronicles Mandela's formative years, early career, and 27 years in prison before becoming South Africa's President. The film portrays Mandela as a flawed but driven individual who fought for justice and human rights. Despite its ambition, the movie doesn't quite rise above the crowd, but Mandela's remarkable journey remains compelling. The film received a B- rating, highlighting its well-made and watchable portrayal of the iconic leader.

site_title: SGX to offer more types of orders throughout trading session
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) announced it will offer more types of orders throughout the trading session, starting March 31, to provide investors with greater flexibility and convenience. Market orders and market-to-limit orders will be available throughout the session, while price-triggered orders, including stop and if-touched orders, will also be introduced. This move aims to build on existing features offered by some brokers and enable greater flexibility for investors.

site_title: Finding levity in love
summary: Lionel Richie, a 64-year-old multi-platinum selling artist, continues to perform and tour despite sporadic studio output. The five-time Grammy winner rose from humble beginnings in Tuskegee, Alabama, with The Commodores, and credits his energetic lifestyle as the secret to his longevity. Richie's hits, such as "Can't Slow Down" and "All Night Long," have become staples of 80s pop music, and he attributes his success to being a "hopeless romantic" whose songs have inspired countless weddings and relationships. His "All The Hits All Night Long" tour comes to Singapore next month.

site_title: Inflation target can be reached: BOJ chief
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda expressed confidence that the central bank can achieve its 2% annual inflation target, citing the success of its "supply side" reforms and planned monetary easing. Kuroda also hinted that the yen may fall further against the dollar, despite the US Federal Reserve's "taper" of Treasury bond purchases. The BOJ will maintain super-easy monetary conditions to support the economy, which is nearing its growth targets. Kuroda emphasized the need for supply-side reforms to achieve sustainable economic recovery in Japan.

site_title: 700 Beach up for sale again - as a hotel
summary: Master Contract Services, a Singapore-based property developer, is considering selling the 700 Beach office block, valued at $120 million, as a hotel. The proposed hotel is expected to have 300 rooms and be completed by 2016. Master Contract is reportedly open to selling the asset on a completion basis, potentially for $1 million per room ($300 million). However, market watchers question the pricing, considering Premier Inn's budget hotel positioning. Two property agencies have been tasked to help source potential buyers.

site_title: Sing $ falls after Fed says rate hikes may start in '15
summary: The Singapore dollar fell nearly 1% after US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen announced interest rate hikes could start in early 2015. Experts predict further weakness, with the SGD expected to weaken to 1.29 by end of 2nd quarter and 1.33 by end of 4th quarter this year. US interest rates may rise to 1% by end-2015 and 2.25% by end-2016, which could lead to higher Sibor rates. Home buyers on floating rate loans and importers are advised to relook their loan packages and hedge their forex exposure, respectively.

site_title: Markets cower under shadow of hawkish Fed
summary: Financial markets worldwide retreated after the US Federal Reserve's latest policy statement, which analysts deemed more hawkish. The Fed departed from its 6.5% unemployment target, instead focusing on qualitative assessments of labor market conditions and inflation. Interest rate expectations rose, with the benchmark two-year US Treasury yield increasing 7 basis points. Markets perceived a stronger possibility of higher rates in 2015 and 2016, with the Straits Times Index slipping 0.8% and major industrial indices lower. Analysts warn of greater unpredictability and potential impact on equities, particularly in Singapore and Hong Kong.

site_title: MAS survey forecasters pull back on 2014 growth
summary: Singapore's forecasters have revised their 2014 growth projections down to 3.8% from a 3.9% median forecast in December, citing softer growth expectations for all sectors except manufacturing. The revision was attributed to concerns over China's shadow banking crisis and a slower-than-expected US recovery. Despite the downward adjustment, economists expect 2014's GDP growth to exceed the 3.8% estimate if risk concerns are addressed, with some forecasters predicting growth at or beyond the government's 2-4% projection.

site_title: 'Trade With Caution': exercise more care
summary: Singapore Exchange's (SGX) Trade With Caution (TWC) notice, introduced to signal caution in unusual price movements, has encountered teething problems, leading to criticism from listed companies and brokers. The TWC is triggered when a company cannot explain unusual price or volume activity, and its reply to the standard query does not reveal undisclosed information. However, the current system may issue TWCs too frequently, diluting their impact, and the exchange is considering a more nuanced approach, taking into account each case's unique features and company explanations.

site_title: Albedo refutes Malaysian report of scuttled RTO deal
summary: Albedo, a steel materials supplier, has refuted a Malaysian news report that allegedly scuttled a planned reverse takeover (RTO) deal, citing no mutual agreement to terminate the proposed acquisition. Despite a 53.8% drop in shares, the company remains committed to the deal, which would involve Malaysian tycoon Danny Tan injecting land parcels into Albedo in exchange for control. Albedo's stock was halted trading due to the sudden sell-off, with analysts warning that timely information from the company is necessary to maintain an orderly market.

site_title: Bigger container ships may be holding back recovery
summary: Industry experts warn that larger container ships may hinder the recovery of the container shipping market due to cascading effects on pricing, feedering segments, and smaller vessels. The introduction of mega-carriers has forced shipowners to adjust pricing decisions, with many adopting the "go big or go home" mantra. Experts predict that smaller vessels will remain in demand due to infrastructure and functional needs, but may face challenges from terminals that need to improve productivity to support larger ships.

site_title: Fully convertible yuan seen before 2020
summary: China's renminbi currency is nearing full liberalization, with economists predicting it may happen in the next two to three years, ahead of the official 2020 target. Low inflation, a stable trade surplus, and the currency being near its equilibrium value have created a window of opportunity for China to liberalize its capital account. This could lead to a multiple reserve currency system, with the US dollar, euro, and renminbi playing their parts. China is testing out wide-ranging reforms in the Shanghai Free Trade Zone before rolling them out nationwide, with a focus on managing volatility and risks in the forex market.

site_title: It pays to disclose board, CEO remuneration
summary: Singapore-listed companies have largely failed to disclose the remuneration of individual directors and CEOs, despite the need for greater transparency. In a survey, 90% of companies cited confidentiality and fear of poaching as reasons for not fully disclosing CEO and director remuneration. The Code of Corporate Governance recommends disclosure, but companies are also lacking in aligning their remuneration systems with long-term interests and prudent risk-taking, with only 2% planning to address the issue in the next 12 months.

site_title: Bankers increasingly hired for their global insight
summary: The Bank of England has named Nemat Shafik, an Egyptian-born economist, as one of its deputies, marking a shift towards hiring policymakers with global insight. The move reflects the increasing interconnectedness of economies and financial markets worldwide, with events abroad affecting domestic stability. The bank's new international directorate will monitor the world economy and coordinate with foreign counterparts, aiming to benchmark policy and performance to global standards. The hiring follows similar moves by other central banks, including the European Central Bank and the Federal Reserve, as they seek to better regulate banks across borders.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Singapore forecasters expect the economy to expand by 3.8% in 2014, a less optimistic outlook compared to three months ago. Meanwhile, Olam is reportedly considering a bid for Temasek Holdings. In other news, US weekly jobless claims have fallen unexpectedly, and China has urged Southeast Asia to support openness amid US tariffs. Chinese property shares surged on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector, and Reliance Jio has delayed its India IPO.

site_title: Corrections
summary: A corrections notice was published for an article on March 19, 2014, regarding incorrect figures and classifications for various real estate trusts. The errors included an indicative dividend yield for Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust and total returns year-to-date for SPH Reit. The corrections were attributed to data errors from Bloomberg and SGX. MGCCT was also incorrectly classified as retail, not diversified. A note was added to clarify that "Total Returns YTD" factors in unit price changes and distributions.

site_title: Improving prospects seen in 2014
summary: The maritime industry is expected to experience an improving outlook in 2014, driven by Asia's growth and recovery of advanced economies. Key indicators include a 4.6% annual growth rate for Far East-Europe seaborne containerized trade and a 5.8% annual growth rate for intra-Asia seaborne containerized trade. Industry players and policymakers agree that Asia will continue to play a key role in the maritime industry, with growth in bulk commodities, containerized trade, and shipbuilding quality expected to sustain the Asian lead.

site_title: China in talks to buy 150 Airbus jets: sources
summary: China is in talks to buy at least 150 Airbus passenger jets worth $20 billion, potentially including A330 and A320 models, as part of President Xi Jinping's visit to Europe. The deal could include unfrozen purchases of blocked A330s and may involve A350 aircraft. The move aims to reset trade relations between China and Europe after a bumpy year, and could bolster Airbus's presence in China, with a planned "cabin completion" plant for A330s. The deal's size and scope are subject to last-minute talks, with competition from Boeing also a factor.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Global Logistic Properties has leased 53,000 square meters of space at GLP Park Hefei Hi-Tech in Anhui, China, making the facility 100% leased. SP AusNet secured A$450 million debt facilities to refinance debt and fund growth. Otto Marine secured US$21 million in charter contracts for its offshore supply vessel in Vietnam and Australia. Standard & Poor's affirmed Noble Group's ratings, citing a recovery in its agriculture segment and improved operational efficiency.

site_title: Ireland's Nama plans property loan sales at discount
summary: Nama, Ireland's bad bank, plans to sell real estate loans valued at over $528 million, including hotels, offices, and apartments, at a discount. The assets, linked to developer Gerry Conlan, will be sold in quarterly batches, with the first sale expected this year. The sales are driven by rising demand for property and Nama's goal of selling assets valued at $250 million or more each quarter. The group of assets for sale, known as Project Spring, excludes the Mount Carmel hospital in Dublin.

site_title: April launch for Farrer Square medical suites
summary: RB Capital will launch its 42 strata medical suites at Farrer Square in Singapore next month, priced between $4,200 and $7,500 psf, with a focus on the medical tourism market. The suites, which offer high ceilings and luxurious feel, will be available for sale or lease, with priority given to medical professionals. The launch is part of a $450-million integrated development that includes a 300-room five-star hotel and retail podium, and is expected to be ready in 2017.

site_title: More funds for Asia-Pac property: CBRE survey
summary: Investors in the Asia-Pacific region expect to commit more capital to real estate purchases this year, with 64% of respondents anticipating higher purchasing activity compared to last year. The region's total real-estate investment turnover reached a record $90.4 billion in 2013. China is the most preferred market for cross-border investors, followed by Australia and Japan. The office sector is the most popular for investment, with industrial and logistics coming in second. Despite strong investor appetite, the availability of desired assets remains limited, particularly in the industrial and logistics sector.

site_title: Samsonite posts 18.6% rise in FY13 net
summary: Samsonite International, the world's largest travel luggage company, posted an 18.6% rise in full-year net profit to US$176.1 million, driven by a 15% increase in net sales to US$2.04 billion. This marks the first time the company's net sales have crossed the US$2 billion mark. The North American sector grew 24.4% in net sales, while Asia remained the company's largest market. A cash dividend of 5.68 US cents was recommended, up from 2.67 US cents in the prior year.

site_title: UOB starts FX unit for small businesses
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has established a foreign exchange advisory and trading unit specifically for small businesses in South-east Asia, following a surge in demand for FX hedging advice. The move comes as UOB continues to see double-digit growth in its SME segment, but notes that small businesses remain conservative, prioritizing cost management over loan expansion.

site_title: CapitaLand sells remaining stake in Australand
summary: CapitaLand sold its remaining 39.1% stake in Australand Property Group for $970.1m, generating a net gain of $35.7m. The sale, completed through a secondary placement, will allow CapitaLand to deploy funds towards its key markets in Singapore and China. The move simplifies the group's structure, boosting cash holdings to $6.9 billion and reducing gearing to 29%. The sale follows a partial sale in November to improve trading liquidity.

site_title: Toyota distributor Borneo quits motor traders' body
summary: The Motor Traders Association of Singapore (MTA) may soon lose its relevance as its membership continues to decline, with its latest departure being Borneo Motors Singapore, the distributor of Toyota, Lexus, and Hino. The exit leaves the MTA with 26 members, accounting for only 32% of the market share, down from 46% previously. Critics question the association's relevance, citing its inability to represent the majority of the industry and its limited ability to lobby the government on behalf of its members.

site_title: Premium, Grade A office rents keep rising in Q1
summary: Premium and Grade A office rents in Raffles Place and New Downtown have risen 3.6% and 5% respectively in Q1, driven by strong leasing interest and healthy demand. Asia Square Tower 2 has seen significant leasing deals, with over 200,000 sq ft committed in the past six months. Colliers forecasts a full-year 2014 increase of up to 15% for Premium Grade and Grade A office space, with limited new supply and capping rent growth at 15%.

site_title: China finds no terrorist link to nationals on missing jet
summary: Malaysia's search for the missing Malaysia Airlines plane, MH370, has found no terrorist link to the 153 Chinese nationals on board. Intelligence checks revealed no red flags, contradicting China's state media, which had criticized Malaysia's investigation. The plane's first turn off its flight path was allegedly programmed into the Boeing 777's navigation system, possibly by someone in the cockpit. The search area spans over 7.7 million square kilometers, involving 26 countries, and is expected to take several weeks to complete.

site_title: Tembusu launches 2nd bitcoin machine
summary: Tembusu Terminals launched its second bitcoin vending machine in Singapore, despite regulatory attention from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) on money-laundering and terrorist-financing risks. The machines currently only allow cash-in, and Tembusu plans to wait for clearer rules before introducing two-way machines with cash-out options. Other operators, such as Numoni and Coin Republic, are also cautious about implementing cash-out functions due to risks and regulatory uncertainty. The MAS will hold a public consultation on its proposed regulations, which could impact the bitcoin industry in Singapore.

site_title: Predictive analytics 'can boost airlines' ops, profitability'
summary: Airlines can leverage predictive analytics to improve operational decisions and increase profitability in a challenging industry environment. FICO notes rising interest from carriers seeking to protect thin margins due to factors such as volatile fuel prices and expanding budget carriers. The International Air Transport Association revised its 2014 industry outlook downwards, projecting a US$18.7 billion industry profit, down from US$19.7 billion previously.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: A consortium of OUE, Lippo Group, and Caesars Entertainment has received approval to build a casino and integrated resort in South Korea. China's online money market fund growth has exposed cracks in the country's banking system. Toyota distributor Borneo Motors has quit the Motor Traders Association. Temasek's offer for Olam could be a sector re-rating event, while Kerry Logistics may consider a secondary listing on SGX. Confidence in Singapore's trade outlook has jumped, and industrial land prices in Malaysia are expected to rise by 10% this year.

site_title: Trade With Caution not intended as a black mark against companies: SGX
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has introduced a "Trade With Caution" notification to enhance its public queries about unusual price or volume movements in companies' shares. The new tool is not a black mark against the company but a warning to investors to be cautious. After a Jardine Cycle & Carriage (JC&C) share price spike, SGX issued a Trade With Caution notice, which JC&C replied to, citing market forces and recent Indonesian developments. The move aims to increase transparency and encourage companies to provide explanations for unusual price movements.

site_title: Zara owner builds US$10b property empire
summary: Amancio Ortega, the 77-year-old founder of Zara, has built a US$10 billion real estate empire through all-cash offers, outbidding institutional funds and property investors. Over the past four months, he has spent almost US$1 billion on properties in Manhattan, London, Beverly Hills, and Barcelona. Ortega's portfolio includes prime office spaces, shopping districts, and buildings that generate rental income of at least US$290 million. He has taken advantage of Spain's economic woes to acquire buildings at deep discounts, and his properties are valued at US$5.8 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.

site_title: DBS's buy useful but hardly earthshaking
summary: DBS Group Holdings acquired Societe Generale's Asian private banking business for US$220 million, a deal that has been met with muted responses from the investment community. The acquisition is seen as a "useful bolt on" to DBS's private banking business, but is unlikely to have a significant impact on the bank's earnings or capital position. The deal will boost DBS's private banking assets under management to US$85 billion, widening the gap with rival Bank of Singapore. Analysts view the acquisition as a strategic move to enhance DBS's wealth management capabilities, but acknowledge the challenging operating environment for private banks in Asia.

site_title: RB Capital repositioning Robertson Quay assets
summary: RB Capital is investing $50-70 million in a major refurbishment of Gallery Hotel and The Quayside retail podium in Singapore, creating 100,000 sq ft of prime retail space and transforming the properties into upscale boutique hotels and lifestyle destinations. The project is expected to be completed in early 2016, with plans to increase the number of hotel rooms and retail outlets. The repositioning aims to bring energy and excitement to the historic Singapore River area, catering to both residents and tourists.

site_title: Passenger car COE premiums advance
summary: Passenger car COE premiums rose in the second tender of March, with Category A increasing $1,603 to $78,602 and Cat B rising $2,190 to $82,900. In contrast, Cat C for goods vehicles declined $2,411 to $53,891. The sales director attributed the premium increases to the introduction of new models and the end of Q1, which may have led to increased bidding. However, some buyers remain hesitant due to the high current premiums.

site_title: Startups and big firms lift innovation tie-ups
summary: Spring Singapore's Partnerships for Capability Transformation (Pact) programme has facilitated over 160 collaborations between startups and large organizations (LOs) since its launch last year. The programme aims to accelerate innovation and create new products and services through mutually beneficial collaborations. Deputy chief executive Ted Tan stated that Pact fosters innovation and creates new opportunities for startups and LOs. Observers question the programme's feasibility and look for deeper roles from the players and government.

site_title: Slower rise in China new-home prices
summary: China's new-home prices rose 0.2% in February, the slowest pace since October 2012, amid tightened credit and cooling measures. Prices in first-tier cities such as Beijing, Shenzhen, and Guangzhou increased, but at a slower rate than in previous months. The government aims to curb excessive borrowing and regulate the home market, with at least 10 cities implementing measures to calm local property markets. This slowdown is seen as a positive sign for the economy, with economists warning of a "major and more real risk to growth and financial stability" due to the property sector's increasing influence.

site_title: Fullerton hires 3 senior personnel to broaden fund capabilities
summary: Fullerton Fund Management has hired three senior personnel to broaden its investment capabilities. Manraj Sekhon, CEO and CIO, welcomed the additions, stating they will help build the firm's global franchise. Jason Zhu, formerly of Franklin Templeton, will lead China equities, while Ian McCallum, from Bedlam Asset Management, will oversee a global emerging markets strategy. Craig Mitchell, with Capital Group experience, will expand Fullerton's fund offerings with an Asia absolute return equity strategy. The hires aim to meet investor demand for benchmark unconstrained solutions, further solidifying Fullerton's presence globally.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Midas Holdings' unit won 71.9 million yuan (S$14.7 million) in contracts to supply aluminium alloy extrusion profiles for train sets in China. China Fishery Group acquired Copeinca, delisting it from Oslo and Lima stock exchanges. FSL Trust sold two dry bulk vessels for US$23.55 million to save US$3 million in dry dock capital expenditure. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed.

site_title: Guarding against complacency on safety
summary: A 2014 maritime incident involving the 8,000 TEU MOL Comfort, which fractured and sank, has raised concerns about structural strength and cargo safety. An investigation by the Committee on Large Container Ship Safety found buckling deformations in the ship's bottom shell plates, but failed to replicate the conditions that led to the fracture. The committee has recommended temporary safety measures for ships with similar capacities and has called for the implementation of International Maritime Organization guidelines on weighing containers prior to loading.

site_title: S Korea approves foreign-run casino to attract China tourists
summary: South Korea has approved a foreign-run casino, a joint venture between Las Vegas-based Caesars Entertainment and Lippo, near Incheon International Airport. The $2.72 billion project will include hotels, shopping malls, and a casino open only to foreigners. The move aims to attract more Chinese tourists, with the goal of drawing 10 million visitors annually by 2020. The casino industry is expected to bring significant revenue and job creation, with the government planning to ease rules on the sector to boost investment and competitiveness.

site_title: China stocks, currency fall on property concerns
summary: China's stocks and currency fell near an 11-month low due to concerns over the property industry's potential for defaults amid slowing economic growth. The Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.2% and the yuan weakened, with top developers China Vanke and Poly Real Estate plummeting 1.3% and 6.5% respectively. The collapse of Zhejiang Xingrun Real Estate, with 3.5 billion yuan in debt, heightened concerns about credit risks in the industry, prompting analysts to warn of a market bottom not yet in sight.

site_title: Suntec Reit tops with YTD returns of 11.1%
summary: Suntec Reit tops the list with a 11.1% year-to-date return, followed by CapitaRetail China Trust with 8.4% and Cambridge Industrial Trust with 5.5%. Analysts attribute Suntec's growth to increased occupancy and higher office building rents. The FTSE ST Reits Index generated 2.2% total returns, outperforming the Straits Times Index. The sector's average year-to-date return was 1.4%, with an indicative dividend yield of 6.3%.

site_title: Chinese property developer near insolvency: sources
summary: Chinese property developer Zhejiang Xingrun is on the verge of insolvency, owing 2.4 billion yuan to banks and 1.1 billion yuan to individual investors. The company's owner has been detained for illegal fund-raising, and regulatory concerns have led to numerous court cases. The financial situation of Zhejiang Xingrun has rattled investors, with stocks and bonds issued by Chinese real estate companies extending a slump. Experts warn that the situation could lead to a domino effect, with banks tightening liquidity and the economy slowing down.

site_title: DBS starts scheme to help firms unlock trapped cash
summary: DBS Bank launched a working capital advisory programme, a worldwide first, to help companies analyse their cash flow and physical supply chains, aiming to reduce overall banking costs by boosting internal cash flow. The programme uses proprietary benchmarks and diagnostic tools to identify and unlock "trapped cash" estimated at US$2.7 trillion in Asian companies. The pilot programme showed a 20-30% increase in cash flow generated from operations for participating companies, and the programme is available to DBS clients at no cost, with over 600 staff members trained to support the initiative.

site_title: Suntec Reit raising $341m to repay debt
summary: Suntec Reit is raising $341 million through a private placement of new units to repay debt. The move will dilute distributions per unit by 3.9-8.4% from FY14 to FY16, but analysts believe the funds may be used for acquisitions, including potential purchases in Singapore and Australia. Analysts have expressed concerns that the move is a "costly way to shrink debt" and may not be the most efficient use of funds, given the low cost of debt financing.

site_title: LATAM Airlines posts net loss of US$46.1m for Q4
summary: LATAM Airlines reported a Q4 net loss of $46.1 million, exceeding forecasts, due to a 2.1% revenue drop and a $142.6 million foreign exchange loss from the Brazilian real's depreciation. The company attributed the loss to weaker passenger and cargo revenue, and said it expects an operating margin of 6-8% for 2014. LATAM's full-year 2013 net loss was $281.1 million, down from $523.1 million in 2012. The airline has $3.06 billion in fleet investment commitments between 2014 and 2015.

site_title: Tension boils over in lead up to this year's Festival of Arts
summary: Singapore Festival of Arts (Sifa) director Ong Keng Sen sent a strongly-worded email to CEO Lee Chor Lin, accusing her of keeping him in the dark about festival brochures. The email was copied to top arts officials and media outlets, citing a lack of proofs since March 11. Lee defended her approach, citing concerns over reader ergonomics and design. Despite a disagreement, both parties have expressed commitment to the festival's success. The incident is the latest in a series of disagreements between the two, who have previously patched up their differences.

site_title: Temasek offer a sector re-rating event: Barclays
summary: Temasek Holdings' offer for Olam International may trigger a sector re-rating, as the market fails to recognize the potential for long-term growth in the soft commodities sector. Strategic shareholders, such as China Investment Corp and Archer Daniels Midland, are considering stepping in if the equity market undervalues Olam. Analysts at Barclays note that the offer reflects a long-term view on the key drivers of the business, including constrained upstream productive resources and demand growth in emerging markets.

site_title: Li's Watson to raise up to US$6b in IPO: report
summary: Li Ka-shing's AS Watson plans to raise up to US$6 billion through a dual listing in Hong Kong and London, the world's largest IPO since 2012. The IPO, expected to be completed by the end of June, will be handled by HSBC, Goldman Sachs, and Bank of America. AS Watson, part of Hutchison Whampoa, owns health and beauty retailer Superdrug and ParknShop grocery chain. The move comes after Hutchison Whampoa reported a 20% year-on-year increase in net profits in 2013.

site_title: OUE, Lippo, Caesars in S Korea casino project
summary: A consortium led by OUE Limited, Lippo Group, and Caesars Entertainment has received preliminary approval from the South Korean government to build the country's first foreign-owned casino integrated resort (IR). The project, estimated to cost 855 billion Korean won (S$1 billion), will feature a foreigners-only casino, hotel, retail, convention, and residential components, and is expected to be ready for the 2018 Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang. The project aims to attract 10 million Chinese visitors annually by 2020, creating over 8,000 jobs and generating significant tourism income.

site_title: Missing MAS jet flew into southern Indian Ocean?
summary: Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370, carrying 239 people, is believed to have flown into the southern Indian Ocean, rather than the northern corridor initially thought. Investigators based their assumption on the lack of evidence from northern countries and the failure to find wreckage in the upper part of the southern corridor. The plane was deliberately diverted thousands of kilometers off course, but no explanation has been found for the diversion. The search for the Boeing 777-200ER is ongoing with 26 nations involved, with China reporting no signs of the aircraft crossing into its territory.

site_title: Yuan no longer a one-way bet
summary: China's renminbi currency, once seen as a one-way bet, has become increasingly volatile, weakening 1.6% against the US dollar this year. The People's Bank of China has widened the trading band to 2% per day, potentially driving away speculators. China's financial overhaul plans, including freeing up interest rates and modernizing the financial system, are expected to redefine the nation's state-driven growth model and impact economies globally. The government is taking steps to show that China's currency is not a one-way bet, but analysts question how much economic pain Beijing is willing to endure for the sake of these reforms.

site_title: Blackstone slows home buying as prices surge
summary: Blackstone Group, the US's largest single-family home landlord, is slowing its house rental acquisitions due to soaring prices. The firm's acquisition pace has declined 70% from its peak last year, when it spent over $100 million weekly on properties. Blackstone now focuses on cities like Seattle, Atlanta, and Miami, having invested $8 billion since 2012 on 43,000 homes. Rising prices have led to a reduction in purchases, with the company narrowing its focus to select locations.

site_title: Moody's: Olam bid by Temasek credit negative
summary: Temasek Holdings launched a $5.33 billion cash offer for all remaining shares of Olam International, valuing the agri-commodities firm at an 11.8% premium. Moody's rated the offer as "credit negative" due to Temasek's high concentration of investment in Singapore-listed companies, which can reduce portfolio liquidity. The offer price represents a premium over Olam's last traded price, and analysts believe the surge in share price may be partly due to rival suitors interested in acquiring the company.

site_title: MH370 flown into navigational black hole
summary: Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 vanished from radar on March 8, 2014, after a deliberate act by someone on board, possibly a pilot or passenger with advanced knowledge. The person turned off the transponder and ACARS system, creating a navigational black hole that delayed the raising of the alarm by controllers. The flight was in a technically obscure sweet spot, making it difficult for radar to detect, and the timing of the actions suggests meticulous planning. The investigation into the hijacking or sabotage is ongoing, with police searching the backgrounds of passengers and examining the flight's systems.

site_title: China money market funds expose cracks in banking
summary: China's largest money market fund, Yu E Bao, launched by Alibaba Group, has exposed cracks in the country's banking system as regulators attempt to reduce reliance on cheap money. The fund, now managing over $102 billion, lends to big and mid-sized banks, bypassing the interbank market due to a prolonged credit squeeze. Critics say it threatens traditional banking, while supporters praise it for redistributing profits to small investors, hastening interest rate liberalization. The fund's growth has raised concerns about its impact on banks' funding costs and the overall financial system.

site_title: Q&M buys dental clinic for $5.5m in shares
summary: Q&M Dental Group has agreed to purchase a dental clinic in Singapore's Orchard Road district valued at $5.5 million in an all-share transaction. The vendor, Foo Mooh Thong, will guarantee an annual profit of at least $525,000 over 10 years. If the guarantees are not met, Q&M can demand the shortfall be made up or terminate the agreement. This acquisition marks Q&M's expansion in Singapore and Malaysia, with analysts predicting strong earnings growth due to the short break-even periods of new outlets.

site_title: DBS's latest purchase widens gap with BOS
summary: DBS Bank has agreed to buy Societe Generale's Asian private banking business for US$220 million, significantly increasing its wealth-management business and narrowing the gap with rival Bank of Singapore. The deal will boost DBS's assets under management to S$85 billion, representing about 23% growth, and is expected to be earnings-per-share accretive within two to three years. The acquisition will also bring in experienced employees and a proven track record in structured products and derivatives, further enhancing DBS's private banking capabilities.

site_title: Making investments, projects more 'visible'
summary: A financial institution discovered $100 million in hidden IT projects, highlighting the need for better visibility in investments and projects. A CA Technologies survey found that only 27% of IT executives evaluate the impact of shifts in investments, and 35% of IT expenditure is now happening outside of the IT department, leading to "cloud sprawl." There is a growing demand for business-oriented IT personnel to bridge the gap between IT and business strategy, with knowledge of business strategies, processes, and communication skills being more frequently mentioned than technical skills.

site_title: Medical suites looking good to investors
summary: Medical suites in Singapore are gaining popularity among investors, driven by the growth of the medical industry and fewer restrictions on commercial property. Around 30% of new suites are being sold to investors, with prices increasing by 40% since 2010. New developments, such as Connexion and SBF Center, are offering medical suites for sale to both doctors and investors, with some units selling out quickly. Consultants predict steady growth in prices due to the increasing demand for medical facilities, driven by the expansion of the healthcare industry and medical tourism.

site_title: Industry players see dry bulk making strong rebound
summary: Dry bulk shipping is expected to experience a strong rebound in the coming years, driven by growth in commodity cargoes such as iron ore and coal, particularly in China and India. Industry players believe these two countries will lead the recovery of the dry bulk market, with China being the main driver. The sector's potential spillover effect is also expected to impact other areas, including the offshore and marine segment, container shipping, and carbon efficiency. Despite concerns over carbon emissions, the dry bulk sector is seen as a promising area for growth, with potential opportunities for improvement in earnings and efficiency.

site_title: Boost for inflation-linked ETFs
summary: The Federal Reserve's efforts to lift inflation to its 2% target are gaining traction in the bond market. Investors are buying inflation-linked exchange-traded funds (ETFs) for the first time in 19 months, driven by rising expectations of consumer spending and hourly earnings. This shift reverses last year's decline in Treasury Inflation Protected Securities (TIPS), which posted their worst losses since 1997. The increase in inflation expectations suggests investors now believe the US economy is strong enough to push inflation towards the Fed's target.

site_title: CIT completes acquisition of Teban Gardens building from EuroSports
summary: CAMBRIDGE Industrial Trust (CIT) has completed the acquisition of the three-storey industrial building at 30 Teban Gardens Crescent from EuroSports Auto for $41 million. EuroSports Global plans to fund a one-time special dividend of $6-8 million to shareholders by selling the building. The dividend would translate to a yield of more than 10% per share, based on the share capital and closing share price.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: SGX has cautioned investors to exercise caution on Swissco Holdings due to unusual price and volume movements. Allied Technologies and Suntar Eco-City clarified their watch-list removal dates. China New Town Development Company's auditors flagged concerns over the company's ability to continue as a going concern due to its reliance on new share subscriptions. Meanwhile, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, and Singapore stocks continued their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: SGX's new rule: clarity needed
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) recently introduced a new rule requiring listed companies to notify SGX confidentially of discussions that could lead to a takeover. However, the rule's effectiveness has been called into question after Temasek Holdings made an offer for Olam International, raising concerns about its practical implementation. The rule's ambiguity on notification timing, stages, and responsibility sharing has left companies uncertain about how to comply, and SGX's enforcement mechanism remains unclear, raising doubts about the rule's overall impact.

site_title: Vancouver port truckers' strike to continue
summary: A two-and-a-half week container truck driver strike at Port Metro Vancouver, Canada's largest port, is set to continue after a government and port authority plan failed to address drivers' concerns. The 14-point plan, which includes fair pay and reduced wait times, was rejected by the striking drivers, who include unionized and independent truckers. The strike has crippled operations, delaying the transport of hundreds of millions of dollars worth of goods. The port authority has threatened to suspend or terminate permits of drivers who refuse to provide services.

site_title: Most firms here won't disclose directors' pay: poll
summary: A survey by the Singapore Institute of Directors and Singapore Exchange found that most Singapore companies won't disclose directors' pay, and only a handful pay attention to gender equality. The survey also revealed that boards are focused on providing functional expertise rather than strategic functions. The Singapore Code of Corporate Governance, updated in 2012, aimed to improve corporate governance, but its guidelines are not being followed by most firms. The lack of transparency and focus on functional expertise is a concern for corporate governance in Singapore.

site_title: Auditor flags concerns about Transcu's financial status
summary: Transcu Group, a struggling biotech firm, has raised concerns about its financial status due to a significant increase in liabilities over current assets. Its independent auditor, Nexia TS Public Accounting Corporation, flagged this issue in an "emphasis of matter" note, stating that the group's current liabilities surpassed its current assets by US$16.6 million as of March 31, 2013. This marks a wider gap than the previous year. The company has been in the red for three years and is facing funding challenges, with its board taking measures to continue operations, including a non-binding memorandum of understanding with Straits Construction Group.

site_title: A good balance of flavours
summary: Royal Pavilion, a modern Cantonese eatery in Park Regis Singapore, offers a balance of flavors in its dishes, reflecting head chef Chung Ho Shi's confident style. The restaurant's dishes, such as coffee-infused smoked salmon and foie gras, are creatively prepared without straying too far from traditional Cantonese cuisine. Standout items include the fried carrot cake with XO-like sauce, foie gras combination plate, and deep-fried Hokkaido scallop in Thai sauce. The restaurant's pricing is reasonable, and the service is commendable. With room for tweaking, Royal Pavilion is off to a promising start, with chef-owner Chung Ho Shi aiming to open more locations in Park Regis hotels worldwide. Rating: 7/10.

site_title: S'pore private home sales up in Feb
summary: Private home sales in Singapore increased in February, with 724 units sold, up from 565 units in January and 712 units last year. The majority of sales were outside the central region, with developers launching 671 units islandwide. However, property consultants expect sales to slow in March due to a cautious market and lack of new launches. Some developers have increased marketing efforts for existing projects, while others have postponed upcoming launches. Total sales in March are expected to be around 650 units, with some predicting a decline to below 350 units.

site_title: Taiwan mindful of Fukushima lessons
summary: Taiwan is commemorating the third anniversary of the Fukushima nuclear disaster with large protests demanding the halt of a new nuclear power plant and removal of radioactive waste. The island, prone to earthquakes, is heavily reliant on nuclear energy, with 20% of its power coming from three operating plants. The government aims to phase out nuclear energy gradually, with a new plant set to buy time for the development of renewable energy sources. However, concerns over safety and environmental impact persist, with protesters warning that the public and industry are not yet prepared for the transition.

site_title: TTI query, trade caution a regulatory overkill?
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) may be overregulating the market, as seen in the case of TT International (TTI), a company queried about unusual volume traded and a "Trade With Caution" warning. The exchange had previously explained that it takes into account various factors when deciding whether price movements are unusual, including macroeconomic factors, market sentiment, and company developments. However, in TTI's case, the company had released significant positive announcements on the SGX website, which likely explained the share price rise and volume increase. The query and warning may be seen as unnecessary, raising questions about the effectiveness of SGX's regulatory approach.

site_title: SIA passenger carriage down in Feb
summary: SINGAPORE AIRLINES (SIA) reported a 2.1% decline in passenger carriage in February, partly due to softer demand for Bangkok flights amidst political protests. Capacity was scaled back by 0.4%, resulting in a 1.4% drop in passenger load factor to 76.8%. The decline was also attributed to Chinese New Year demand shifting to January. Regional wing SilkAir saw a 0.3% rise in passenger carriage, while SIA Cargo reported a 11.1% drop in cargo traffic.

site_title: New global debt crisis could be brewing: IIF
summary: A new report from the Institute for International Finance (IIF) warns of a potential global debt crisis, citing a 40% increase in global debt since 2007 to over $100 trillion, equivalent to 135% of world GDP. Emerging economies, including China, are particularly vulnerable, with corporate debt-to-GDP ratios reaching 80-145%. The IIF warns that this high debt load makes it difficult for these corporations to service their debt, especially with slowing growth rates and rising interest rates ahead.

site_title: Australia takes lead role in search for missing jet
summary: Malaysia focuses on investigating the pilots' possible role in diverting the missing Malaysia Airlines Boeing 777-200, which vanished 10 days ago with 239 people on board. Australia takes the lead in the southern search zone, while Malaysia cooperates with the FBI and Interpol. Initial investigations suggest the co-pilot last made contact with air traffic controllers before the plane disappeared. The investigation is also focusing on the pilots, including Zaharie Ahmad Shah and Fariq Abdul Hamid, and has seized a flight simulator from the pilot's home.

images.alt_text: Mr Ahmad Jauhari: Last contact with controllers was made by the co-pilot

site_title: MH370 mystery may spur redesign of switches
summary: Malaysia Airlines' MH370 flight mysteriously vanished from radar screens after communications with air traffic controllers were severed, raising concerns about the security of modern aircraft systems. The jet's transponder and satellite-linked communication systems were disabled, leaving investigators with limited data. Experts suggest redesigning switches to prevent such incidents and adopting real-time satellite tracking to improve safety. The incident highlights the need for enhanced security measures to prevent similar disappearances in the future.

site_title: Annual yacht show gets bigger, better
summary: The Singapore Yacht Show (SYS) is set to take place from April 10 to 13, featuring over 100 vessels worth over half a billion dollars. The event is expected to attract more than 12,000 attendees, including high net-worth individuals, and is considered the premier industry event in Asia. The show's growth reflects Singapore's growing position as a luxury yachts hub, with the city-state ranking third globally for resident multi-millionaires. Organisers expect an estimated $20 million in economic value from visitors and exhibitors.

site_title: Qantas tops France-KLM in credit-default risk
summary: Qantas Airways has seen its credit-default risk rise to a record high, surpassing that of Air France-KLM Group, due to concerns over the carrier's ability to stem losses. Credit-default swaps protecting Qantas's debt have increased by 48 basis points to 300, the highest level since November 2012, amid doubts over the airline's cost-cutting plan. Qantas faces a decline in annual revenue and negative free cash flow, with analysts warning that the plan may not be enough to turn around the business.

site_title: Int'l Healthway buys 2 more Aussie properties
summary: International Healthway Corporation (IHC) has acquired two freehold properties in Melbourne and Geelong, Australia, for A$63.8 million ($73.4 million). The properties include an eight-storey commercial building with a net leasable area of 8,229 sq m and a four-storey medical-use building with a net leasable area of 5,172 sq m. The acquisitions will further entrench IHC's presence in Australia, providing facilities and services to meet the health-care needs of residents. The company's total net leasable area in Australia now amounts to 23,571 sq m.

site_title: EU deal on airline emissions faces opposition
summary: EU politicians plan to vote against a deal exempting long-haul flights from paying for carbon emissions until the end of 2016, potentially re-igniting tensions with major trading partners. The "stop the clock" measure would automatically apply an existing law requiring all aviation to pay for emissions, but environmentalists see it as a compromise. The European Parliament's Environment Committee will vote on the proposal, with some groups, including the Greens and liberal ALDE, opposing the deal, while the centre-right EPP is in favor.

site_title: HTC, Huawei cleared in US patent dispute
summary: US International Trade Commission rules HTC Corp, Huawei Technologies, and ZTE Corp did not violate digital camera patents owned by FlashPoint Technology, clearing them in a patent dispute. FlashPoint Technology had originally accused the firms of infringing four patents for smartphone cameras. A preliminary decision in 2013 found two HTC smartphones infringed on one patent, while Huawei and ZTE were cleared in the case.

site_title: S'pore exports up 9.1% in February, beating forecast
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) rose 9.1% in February, beating forecast, driven by a 49.3% surge in petrochemicals. Electronics, which accounts for 30% of exports, fell for the 19th straight month. While some economists see the surge as a sign of underlying momentum, others caution that the growth may be temporary and that domestic capacity constraints could hinder exports. The NODX growth rate averaged 2.9% on-year, and 1.1% month on month, according to some economists.

site_title: Fears over S'pore banks 'overdone'
summary: Singaporean banks' stock prices have taken a beating this year, with shares down 6-8% year-to-date, attributed to fears of potential pitfalls from increased exposure to China. Analyst Ng Wee Siang of Maybank-Kim Eng calls the fears "overdone." Despite a slight uptick yesterday, the sector's performance is still concerning. The analyst suggests that the banks' selective lending practices may be a factor in the market's concerns.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: DBS Bank announced a $220 million purchase of Societe Generale's Asian private banking business. A survey found most Singapore companies won't disclose director compensation, despite new corporate governance guidelines.
